dataPull.name: Behavioral

fields: {{c1::Neurons}} are the basic working unit of the brain; a specialized cell designed to transmit information to other nerve cells, muscle, or gland cells
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Reflex arcs}} are when interneurons in the spinal cord relay info to the source of stimuli while simultaneously routing it to the brain
YouTube Link
The central nervous system is made up of the {{c1::brain}} and {{c1::spinal cord}}
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::peripheral}} nervous system consists of nervous tissue and fibers outside the CNS
Khan Academy Link
The part of the nervous system that is responsible for fight / flight is the {{c1::sympathetic nervous system}}
Khan Academy Link
The part of the nervous system that is responsible for <u>rest / digest</u> is the {{c1::parasympathetic nervous system}}

Remember P for Parasympathetic: "Relaxing and having a Piña colada on beach"


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Neurotransmitters}} are released by neurons to carry a signal
Khan Academy Link
Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter used to {{c1::move muscles}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Dopamine}} is a neurotransmitter involved in focus and motivation as well as maintaining smooth movements and steady posture
Khan Academy Link
Endorphins & Enkephalins are neurotransmitters that are used as {{c1::pain killers}}
Khan Academy Link
Epinephrine & Norepinephrine maintain {{c1::wakefulness}} and mediate the {{c1::fight / flight responses}}
Khan Academy Link
γ-aminobutyric Acid (GABA) is an {{c1::inhibiting::excitatory or inhibiting}} neurotransmitter

Glycine serves a similar function


Khan Academy Link
Glutamate is an {{c1::excitatory::excitatory or inhibiting}} neurotransmitter
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Serotonin}} modulates mood, sleep, eating, and dreaming
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Cortisol}} is a stress hormone released by the adrenal cortex
Khan Academy Link
Testosterone and estrogen are hormones that mediate {{c1::libido}} among other functions

Testosterone is also associated with aggressive behavior



Khan Academy Link - Estrogen 
Khan Academy Link - Testosterone
The {{c1::hindbrain::division of brain}} includes the <u>cerebellum</u>, the <u>medulla oblongata</u>, and the <u>reticular formation</u>
YouTube Link
The {{c1::midbrain::division of brain}} includes the colliculi, the tegmentum, and the cerebral peduncles
YouTube Link
The {{c1::forebrain::division of brain}} includes the thalamus, the hypothalamus, the basal ganglia, the limbic system, and the cerebral cortex
YouTube Link
The {{c1::thalamus::brain area}} is the relay station for sensory information

Part of the forebrain


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::hypothalamus::brain area}} regulates homeostasis and is in charge of the 4 F's

Integrates with the endocrine system

Part of the forebrain


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::basal ganglia::brain area}} controls <u>smooths movements</u> and helps <u>postural stability</u>

Part of the forebrain


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::limbic system::brain area}} deals with emotions, memories, and arousal (or stimulation)

Part of the forebrain


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::amygdala::limbic system structure}} is in charge of fear and aggression
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::hippocampus::limbic system structure}} regulates emotions
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::cerebral cortex::brain structure}} is the outer layer of neural tissue of the cerebrum

Four lobes:

Frontal
Parietal
Temporal
Occipital


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::parietal lobe::... lobe}} is associated with touch, pressure, temp, pain, and spatial processing
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::frontal lobe::... lobe}} is associated with <u>executive function</u>, <u>impulse control</u>, <u>speech</u>, and <u>motor</u>
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::occipital lobe::... lobe}} is associated with vision
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::temporal lobe::... lobe}} is associated with sound, speech perception, memory, and emotion
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::left::left or right}} cerebral hemisphere is associated with analytic thinking, language, logic, and math
YouTube Link
The {{c1::right::left or right}} cerebral hemisphere is associated with intuition, creativity, and spatial processing
YouTube Link
The rooting, moro, babinski, and grasping reflexes are examples of {{c1::primitive reflexes}}

They exist in infants and should disappear with age


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::rooting reflex::... reflex}} is when an infant turns his or her head toward a stimulus
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::moro reflex::... reflex}} is when an infant <u>extends his or her arms</u> in response to a <u>falling sensation</u>
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::babinski reflex::... reflex}} is when an infant's big toe is extended and other toes fan out in response to brushing on sole of foot
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::grasping reflex::... reflex}} is when an infant grabs anything put into hands
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Sensory receptors}} are sensory nerves that respond to stimuli
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Sensory ganglia}} are enlargements along peripheral nerves that <u>transmit signals to the CNS</u>
Khan Academy Link
Projection areas are areas in the four lobes (frontal, parietal, temporal, occipital) of the brain where {{c1::sensory processing}} occurs
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::absolute threshold}} is the minimum stimulus energy that will activate a sensory system
YouTube Link
The {{c1::threshold of conscious perception}} is the minimum stimulus energy that will create a signal large enough in size and long enough in duration to be brought into awareness
The {{c1::difference threshold}} is the minimum difference in magnitude between two stimuli before one can perceive the difference
Khan Academy Link
Weber’s law states that the just noticeable difference for a stimulus is proportional to the {{c1::magnitude}} of the stimulus
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Signal detection theory::... theory}} refers to the effects of nonsensory factors, such as experiences, motives, and expectations on perception of stimuli

Accounts for the response bias


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Sensory adaptation}} can increase or decrease our receptors sensitivity to the stimulus

Amplification = an increase in sensitivity


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::cornea::eye structure}} <u>gathers and filters</u> incoming light

The eye's outermost layer


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::iris::eye structure}} controls the size of the pupil

It is the colored part of eye


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::lens::eye structure}} refracts incoming light to focus it on the retina
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Aqueous humor}} is the clear, watery fluid that fills the space between the cornea and lens of the eye. It provides pressure to maintain the shape of the eyeball

Produced by the ciliary body

Drains through the canal of Schlemm


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::retina::eye structure}} is the sensory membrane that lines the back of the eye

Contains rods and cones


Khan Academy Link
Rods are photoreceptors in the retina that detect {{c1::light / dark}}

Contain rhodopsin


Khan Academy Link
<u>Cones</u> are photoreceptors in the retina that detect {{c1::color}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Retinal disparity}} provides a binocular cue that facilitates depth perception

In the example below, the hand remains stationary, but the two eyes have a slightly different view due to the fact that there is space between the eyes. The brain uses this information to perceive depth


Khan Academy Link
Horizontal and amacrine cells integrate signals from ganglion cells and perform {{c1::edge-sharpening}}
{{c1::Magnocellular}} cells process motion

Gives us the "where" of an object


Khan Academy Link
<u>Parvocellular</u> cells process {{c1::shape}}

Gives us the "what" of an object


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Parallel processing}} is the idea that our eyes process color, form, and motion at same time
Khan Academy Link

Give the visual pathway:

{{c1::Eye}} → {{c1::optic nerves}} → {{c1::optic chiasm}} → {{c1::optic tracts}} → {{c1::lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN)}} → {{c1::visual radiations}} → {{c1::visual cortex}}
YouTube Link

The item missing from the visual pathway:

Eye → optic nerves → optic chiasm → optic tracts → {{c1::lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN)}} → visual radiations → visual cortex
YouTube Link
The three main divisions of the ear are {{c1::outer}}, {{c1::middle}}, and {{c1::inner}}
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::outer}} ear includes the <u>pinna</u> (auricle), <u>external auditory canal</u>, and the <u>tympanic membrane</u>

Collects sound and transmits to eardrum


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::middle}} ear includes the malleus, the incus, and the stapes

Malleus: Hammer

Incus: Anvil

Stapes: Stirrup. Footplate of stapes rests in the oval window of cochlea

Ossicles Acronym: MIS and HAS


Khan Academy Link
The malleus is one of three ossicles in the middle ear and is the {{c1::hammer}}
Khan Academy Link
The incus is one of three ossicles in the middle ear and is the {{c1::anvil}}
Khan Academy Link
The <u>stapes</u> is one of three <u>ossicles</u> in the middle ear and is the {{c1::stirrup}}
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::inner}} ear includes the cochlea, the vestibular system, and the semicircular canals

Cochlea: Hearing

Vestibular System: Balance

Semicircular Canals: Balance (part of the vestibular system)


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::pinna (auricle)::ear structure}} acts as a kind of funnel which assists in directing the sound further into the ear
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::External auditory canal::Ear structure}} transmits sound <u>from the pinna to the eardrum</u>

"Ear canal"


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Tympanic membrane::Ear structure}} is a thin flap of skin that is stretched tight like a drum and vibrates when sound hits it

"Eardrum"

Separates the outer ear from the middle ear


Khan Academy Link
The <u>cochlea</u> translates sound into {{c1::nerve impulses}} to be sent to the brain
Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::vestibular system::ear structure}} is a sensory system responsible for providing our brain with information about motion, head position, and spatial orientation; it also is involved with motor functions that allow us to keep our balance

The vestibular system includes the semicircular canals


YouTube Link
Semicircular canals are responsible for {{c1::balance}}

When your head moves around, the endolymph (liquid) inside the semicircular canals sloshes around and moves the tiny hairs that line each canal



Khan Academy Link
The superior olive is located in the {{c1::brain stem}} and its function is to {{c1::localize sound}}
YouTube Link
The {{c1::inferior colliculus::ear structure}} is responsible for the startle reflex and vestibulo-ocular reflex
YouTube Link
The {{c1::vestibulo-ocular reflex::... reflex}} keeps the eyes fixed on a single point as the head rotates

Give the auditory pathway:

{{c1::Cochlea}} → {{c1::vestibulocochlear nerve}} → {{c1::medial geniculate nucleus}} → {{c1::auditory cortex}}
Khan Academy Link

Identify the item missing from the auditory pathway:

Cochlea → vestibulocochlear nerve → {{c1::medial geniculate nucleus}} → auditory cortex
Khan Academy Link
<u>Smell</u> is the detection of volatile or aerosolized chemicals by the {{c1::olfactory}} chemoreceptors

Smell info bypasses the thalamus


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Pheromones}} are chemicals given off by animals that have an effect on social foraging, and sexual behavior
Khan Academy Link

The five categories of taste are:

{{c1::Sweet}}
{{c1::Sour}}
{{c1::Salty}}
{{c1::Bitter}}
{{c1::Umamai}}

Taste is the detection of dissolved compounds by taste buds in papillae


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Somatosensation}} refers to the four touch modalities: pressure, vibration, pain, and temperature
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::two-point threshold}} is the minimum distance necessary between two points of stimulation on the skin such that the points will be felt as two distinct stimuli
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Physiological zero}} is a temperature that is felt by the skin as neither warm nor cold
Under ordinary conditions usually falls at about 85° to 90°F
Nociceptors sense {{c1::pain}}

There is a lower just noticeable difference for pain


Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::gate control theory::... theory}} of pain asserts that non-painful input closes the nerve "gates" to painful input, which prevents pain sensation from traveling to the central nervous system
YouTube Link
{{c1::Proprioception}} is the sense that tells you information about your body's position

Proprioception = your body's position

Kinaesthesia = your body's movements


Khan Academy Link
Top-down processing is the recognition of an object by {{c1::memories and expectations}}

Little attention to detail

Uses background knowledge


Khan Academy Link
Using bottom-up processing, one will process {{c1::details}} first, then the {{c1::whole object}}

Recognition of objects by feature detection

Not influenced by background knowledge


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Gestalt principles}} are principles of how our mind groups things

Proximity
Similarity
Continuity
Subjective contours
Closure


Khan Academy Link
According to the gestalt principle of {{c1::proximity}}, objects that are placed <u>close</u> together are <u>perceived as being more related</u> than those spaced farther apart

In the below example, your mind sees set (a) as one group and set (b) as three distinct columns or groups


Khan Academy Link
According to the gestalt principle of {{c1::similarity}}, we tend to perceive things that physically resemble one another as part of the same object
Khan Academy Link
According to the gestalt principle of {{c1::continuity}}, when a shape is not complete, but enough of the shape is shown, our minds will fill in the blanks and construct the whole of the shape

In the below example, the eye tends to want to follow the straight line from one end of this figure to the other, and the curved line from the top to the bottom, even when the lines change color midway through


Khan Academy Link
According to the gestalt principle of {{c1::closure}}, we tend to see complete figures even when part of the information is missing
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Law of Prägnanz}} states that people will perceive and interpret ambiguous or complex images as the <u>simplest form(s) possible</u>

The Law of Prägnanz governs all the Gestalt Principles


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Habituation}} is when one becomes used to a stimulus
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Dishabituation}} may occur after habituation and is when a second stimulus intervenes causing a resensitization of the original stimulus
YouTube Link
The {{c1::associative learning}} theory states that ideas reinforce each other and can be linked to one another

Two types: classical conditioning and operant conditioning


YouTube Link
{{c1::Operant conditioning}} is a method of learning that occurs through rewards and punishments for behavior
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Reinforcement}} increases the likelihood of a behavior
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Punishment}} <u>decreases</u> the likelihood of a behavior
Khan Academy Link
<u>Schedules of reinforcement</u> can be based on {{c1::intervals}} or {{c1::the ratio of behavior / reward}}
Khan Academy Link
Positive responses {{c1::add}} something
Khan Academy Link
Negative responses {{c1::remove}} something
Khan Academy Link
When a previously reinforced behavior is no longer reinforced, it becomes {{c1::extinct}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Shaping}} is when behavior that is closer and closer to the target behavior is reinforced
Khan Academy Link
In classical conditioning, a {{c1::neutral stimulus}} becomes a {{c1::conditioned stimulus}} that produces a conditioned response
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Observational learning or modeling}} is the acquisition of behavior by watching others

Example: Bobo doll experiment


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Encoding}} is the process of putting new info into memory

It can be automatic or effortful


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Semantic encoding}} is a specific type of encoding in which the meaning of something is encoded as opposed to the sound or vision of it

Semantic encoding is stronger than both acoustic and visual encoding


YouTube Link
{{c1::Sensory memory::... memory}} and {{c1::short term memory::... memory}} are transient and based on neurotransmitter activity
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Working memory::... memory}} is responsible for temporarily holding information available for processing

Requires short term memory, attention, and executive function to manipulate information



Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Long term memory::... memory}} is responsible for the storage of information for an <u>extended period of time</u>

Requires elaborate rehearsal and is the result of increased neuronal connectivity

Either explicit or implicit


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Explicit (declarative) memory::... memory}} accounts for memories that we must consciously recall with effort and focus

Examples: Facts, data, and events



Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Implicit memory::... memory}} is acquired and used unconsciously

Most memories stored in implicit memory are procedural memories such as recalling how to walk



Khan Academy Link
<u>Semantic networks</u> link concepts together based on similar {{c1::meaning}}

Stores facts. Certain triggers will activate associated memories


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Retrieval}} is re-accessing of events or information from the past

Retrieval is often based on priming interconnected nodes of the semantic network

Two forms of retrieval: Recognition and recall


Khan Academy Link
Alzheimer's is a degenerative brain disorder linked to a loss of {{c1::acetylcholine}} in neurons that link to the {{c1::hippocampus}}

Alzheimer's is a type of dementia and causes memory loss


YouTube Link
Korsakoff’s Syndrome memory loss is caused by a/an {{c1::thiamine (vitamin B1)}} deficiency in the brain

Thiamine is important because it converts carbohydrates into glucose


Khan Academy Link
Agnosia is the loss of ability to recognize {{c1::objects, people, or sounds}}
Usually caused by physical damage to brain
{{c1::Retroactive interference::... interference}} is when new memories make you forget old memories
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Proactive interference::... interference}} is when old memories interfere with learning new memories
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::information processing model::... model}} states that the brain encodes, stores, and retrieves info much like a computer
Khan Academy Link

Piaget’s four stages of cognitive development:

{{c1::Sensorimotor: 0 → 2}}

{{c1::Preoperational: 2 → 7}}

{{c1::Concrete Operational: 7 → 11}}

{{c1::Formal Operational: 12 and older}}
Khan Academy Link
Piaget's <u>sensorimotor</u> stage is from {{c1::0}} to {{c1::2}} years old
Khan Academy Link
Piaget's preoperational stage is from {{c1::2}} to {{c1::7}} years old
Khan Academy Link
Piaget's concrete operational stage is from {{c1::7}} to {{c1::11}} years old
Khan Academy Link
Piaget's <u>formal operational</u> stage is from age {{c1::12}} and older
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Deductive::Deductive or Inductive}} reasoning starts with rules, then forms conclusions
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Inductive::Deductive or Inductive}} reasoning starts with evidence, then forms conclusions
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::mental set}} is a <u>framework</u> for thinking about a <u>problem</u>

It can be shaped by habit or by desire


YouTube Link
{{c1::Functional fixedness}} is the tendency to use objects only in the way they are normally utilized

Creates barriers to problem-solving


YouTube Link
{{c1::Heuristics}} are <u>mental shortcuts</u> that allow people to solve problems and make judgments quickly and efficiently

“Rules of thumb”


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Availability heuristic}} is a mental shortcut that relies on immediate examples that come to a person's mind when evaluating a situation
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Representativeness heuristic}} is a mental shortcut that helps us make a decision by comparing information to our mental prototypes
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Confirmation bias}} is the tendency to focus on information that fits an individual’s beliefs, while rejecting information that goes against those beliefs
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Gardner’s Theory of Multiple Intelligences::Theory}} differentiates human intelligence into specific 'modalities', rather than seeing intelligence as dominated by a single general ability

Linguistic
Logical-mathematical
Musical
Visual-spatial
Bodily-kinesthetic
Interpersonal
Intrapersonal


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Phonology}} refers to the actual <u>sound</u> of speech
YouTube Link
{{c1::Morphology}} refers to the building blocks of words
YouTube Link
{{c1::Semantics}} refers to the meaning of words
YouTube Link
{{c1::Syntax}} refers to the rules dictating word order
YouTube Link
{{c1::Pragmatics}} refers to the way language delivery changes depending on context
YouTube Link
The {{c1::nativist theory::theory}} of language states that <u>language acquisition is innate</u>

Biological control of language acquisition

Humans have a language acquisition device (LAD) that allows them to learn language


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::behaviorist theory::theory}} of language states that language acquisition is controlled by operant conditioning and reinforcement by parents and caregivers
YouTube Link
The {{c1::social interactionist theory::theory}} of language states that language acquisition is caused by a motivation to communicate and interact with others
YouTube Link
The {{c1::Whorfian hypothesis}}, also known as {{c1::linguistic relativity}} states that the lens by which we view and interpret the world is created by language
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Broca's area::Brain area}} <u>produces</u> speech
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Wernicke’s area::Brain area}} is in charge of language comprehension
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::arcuate fasciculus}} connects Broca’s area to the Wernicke’s area
Khan Academy Link
Difficulty <u>producing</u> speech is called {{c1::Broca’s aphasia::disorder}}
Khan Academy Link
A lack of speech comprehension is called {{c1::Wernicke’s aphasia}}
Khan Academy Link
Someone with {{c1::conduction aphasia::disorder}} can’t repeat words
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Alertness}} is the state of being awake and thinking
Khan Academy Link
An EEG shows {{c1::BETA}} waves when alert or concentrating
Khan Academy Link
An EEG shows {{c1::ALPHA}} waves when <u>awake but tired</u>, eyes closed
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Hypnosis}} refers to when individuals appear to be in normal control of their faculties but are in a highly suggestible state

Used for pain control, psychological therapy, memory enhancement

More alpha waves are present in this state. It is an awake but relaxed state


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Meditation}} is the practice of turning one's attention to a single point of reference; quieting of the mind

Used for relief of anxiety


Khan Academy Link
Alcohol, barbiturates, and benzodiazepines are {{c1::depressants::stimulants or depressants}}

They lower the body’s basic functions and neural activity. Lower heart rate and blood pressure


Khan Academy Link
Amphetamines, cocaine, and ecstasy are {{c1::stimulants::stimulants or depressants}}

They excite the nervous system. Increase heart rate and blood pressure


Khan Academy Link
Opiates and opioids can cause death by {{c1::respiratory depression}}

Heroin, morphine, opium, oxycodone & hydrocodone


Khan Academy Link
LSD, peyote, mescaline, and ketamine are considered {{c1::hallucinogens}}
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::mesolimbic}} pathway mediates drug addiction

Includes nucleus accumbens, medial forebrain bundle, and ventral tegmental area

Dopamine is the main neurotransmitter


Khan Academy Link

Give the sleep stages

{{c1::Stage 1}}: Light sleep

{{c1::Stage 2}}: Slightly deeper

{{c1::Stages 3 & 4}}: Deep sleep

{{c1::Rapid Eye Movement}}: REM sleep
Khan Academy Link
During sleep stage 1, {{c1::theta}} waves appear on EEG

Stage 1: theta

Stage 2: theta

Stages 3 & 4: delta

Rapid Eye Movement: beta since the mind appears awake on EEG


Khan Academy Link
Sleep spindles and K complexes appear during stage(s) {{c1::two}} of sleep
Khan Academy Link
Slow-wave sleep (SWS) occurs during stage(s) {{c1::3 and 4}} of sleep
Khan Academy Link
During {{c1::rapid eye movement sleep::sleep stage}}, the mind appears awake on EEG, but the person is asleep

REM phase is distinguishable by random/rapid movement of the eyes, body paralysis, and beta waves on EEG



Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Circadian rhythm}} is a natural, internal process that regulates the sleep-wake cycle and repeats roughly every 24 hours
Khan Academy Link
Dreaming occurs mostly during {{c1::REM::sleep stage}}
Khan Academy Link
The activation-synthesis theory states that dreams are activated in the {{c1::brainstem}} and synthesized in the {{c1::cortex}}
Khan Academy Link
Dyssomnias are conditions that make it difficult to {{c1::fall asleep, stay asleep, or avoid sleep}}

Insomnia
Narcolepsy
Sleep apnea


Khan Academy Link
<u>Parasomnias</u> are conditions that cause {{c1::abnormal movements or behaviors during sleep}}

Night terrors
Sleepwalking


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Selective attention}} allows one to pay attention to particular stimulus while determining if additional stimuli in the background require attention
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Divided attention}} uses automatic processing to pay attention to multiple activities at one time
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Motivation}} is the purpose, or driving force, behind our actions

Can be extrinsic or intrinsic


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Instincts}} are <u>innate,</u> <u>fixed patterns of behavior</u> in response to stimuli
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Instinct theory::... theory}} states that people perform certain behaviors because of their evolutionarily programmed instincts
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Arousal}} is the state of being awake and reactive to stimuli
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Optimal arousal theory::... theory}} states that optimal performance requires optimal arousal

Arousal levels that are too high or too low will impede performance


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Drives}} are internal states of tension that <u>beget particular behaviors focused on goals</u>

Drives reduce needs






Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Drive reduction theory::... theory}} states that people are motivated to take certain actions in order to reduce the internal tension that is caused by unmet needs
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Maslow’s hierarchy of needs}} states that people have a certain needs, and these needs are arranged in a hierarchy, with some needs being more primitive or basic than others
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Self-actualization}} is the <u>full realization of one’s talents and potential</u>
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Self-determination theory::... theory}} is a theory of human motivation and personality and emphasizes 3 universal needs: autonomy, competence, and relatedness
YouTube Link
{{c1::Incentive theory::... theory}} states that behavior is motivated by a desire for reinforcement or incentives
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Expectancy-value theory::... theory}} states that the amount of motivation for a task is based on the expectation of success and the value of that success
YouTube Link
The {{c1::opponent-process theory::... theory}} views emotions as pairs of opposites. For example, fear/relief or pleasure/pain

When one emotion is experienced, the other is suppressed

Explains motivation for drug use: as drug use increases, the body counteracts its effects, leading to tolerance and uncomfortable withdrawal symptoms


YouTube Link
The {{c1::house money effect}} states that after a prior gain, people become more open to assuming risk since the new money is not treated as one's own
It's the tendency of individual investors to take on greater risks when investing with profits attained
The {{c1::gambler’s fallacy}} states that if something happens more frequently than normal, it will happen less frequently in the future, or vice versa
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::prisoner’s dilemma}} is when two people act out of their own self-interest, but if they had cooperated, the result would have been even better
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Covert orienting}} is the act to mentally shifting one's focus without moving one's eyes
