{{c1::Overt orienting}} is the act of selectively attending to an item or location over others by moving the eyes to point in that direction
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Attentional capture}} occurs when attention is attracted by the motion of an object or stimulus

{{c1::Neglect syndrome}} is a neuropsychological condition in which damage to the right parietal lobe causes a person to completely ignore the left side of their world, and even the left side of their body
YouTube Link
{{c1::Vigilance}}, also termed sustained concentration, is defined as the ability to maintain concentrated attention over prolonged periods of time
During this time, the person attempts to detect the appearance of a particular target stimulus
{{c1::Executive attention::... attention}} is involved in goal-directed behavior, monitoring conflicts between internal processes, and anticipating the effects of behavior
A/an {{c1::shadowing task}} is when a study participant wears headphones, is played a different message into each ear, and is asked to repeat aloud just one of those messages
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Broadbent's early selection theory::... theory}} states that all sensory information enters a 'short-term store' or 'buffer' which temporarily holds information before it starts to decay
Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::Deutsch & Deutsch late selection theory::... theory}} states that all information, both attended and unattended, undergo analysis for meaning. After such analysis, selection of a sensory input takes place
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Treisman's attenuation theory::... theory}} proposes that incoming information is restricted at some point in processing, so only a portion of the information gets through to consciousness
Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::spotlight model of attention}} describes how our focus of attention is analogous to the beam of a spotlight; the moveable spotlight is directed at one location and everything within its beam is attended and processed preferentially, while information outside the beam is unattended
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Priming}} is the implicit memory effect in which exposure to a stimulus influences response to a later stimulus

Positive priming speeds up processing

Negative priming causes you to ignore a stimulus


Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::resource model of attention}} states that we have limited resources when it comes to attention and those resources are easily overtasked if we try to pay attention to multiple things at once
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Echoic}} refers to auditory memory

{{c1::Iconic}} refers to visual memory
Khan Academy Link
In iconic memory experiments, the {{c1::whole report technique::... technique}} requires participants to recall as many elements from the original visual display as possible

The partial report condition requires participants to identify a subset of the characters from the visual display using cued recall


YouTube Link
The serial-position effect is the tendency of a person to recall the first and last items in a series {{c1::best::best or worst}}, and the middle items {{c1::worst::best or worst}}
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::visuo-spatial sketchpad}} is the component of working memory responsible for handling visual and spatial information
Khan Academy Link
The phonological loop is a component of working memory model that deals with {{c1::auditory}} information
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::central executive}} acts as supervisory system and controls the flow of information from and to its slave systems: the phonological loop and the visuo-spatial sketchpad
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::dual coding hypothesis}} states that visual and verbal information is coded separately in our brains

The theory states that it is easier to remember words when they are associated with images


YouTube Link
{{c1::Autobiographical memory}} is a memory system consisting of episodes recollected from an individual's life, based on a combination of episodic and semantic memory
Examples might include memories of experiences that occurred in childhood, the first time learning to drive a car, or even one's Social Security number or home address

{{c1::Encoding specificity}} is a principle that states that human memories are more easily retrieved if external conditions (emotional cues) at the time of retrieval are similar to those at the time the memory was stored
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Rote rehearsal}} is deliberate, continuous repetition of material in the same form in which it entered working memory

Examples: memorizing by saying over and over, writing over and over, reading over and over, etc.


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Chunking}} is a process by which individual pieces of an information set are broken down and then grouped together

A chunk is a collection of basic familiar units that have been grouped together and stored in a person's memory


Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::mnemonic device}} is any learning technique that aids information retention or retrieval in the human memory

Imagery
Pegword system
Method of loci
Acronym


Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::self-reference effect::... effect}} is a phenomenon of memory that causes an individual to encode information differently depending on the degree of personal involvement in the sequence of events being encoded
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::spacing effect}} is the phenomenon whereby learning is greater when studying is spread out over time

As opposed to studying the same amount of content in a single session


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Context-dependent learning::... learning}} is the improved recall of specific episodes or information when the context present at encoding and retrieval are the same
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::State-dependent learning::... learning}} is the phenomenon through which memory retrieval is most efficient when an individual is in the same state of consciousness as they were when the memory was formed
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Cued recall}} is the retrieval of memory with the help of cues

Example: A cued recall test is a procedure for testing memory in which a participant is presented with cues, such as words or phrases, to aid recall of previously experienced stimuli


Khan Academy Link
People use {{c1::schemata}} to organize current knowledge and provide a framework for future understanding
Khan Academy Link
A {{c1::source-monitoring error::... error}} is a type of memory error where the source of a memory is incorrectly attributed to some specific recollected experience

An example of a source monitoring error would be incorrectly recalling a conversation that occurred in a dream as having occurred in reality


Khan Academy Link
A {{c1::flashbulb memory}} is a highly detailed, exceptionally vivid 'snapshot' of the moment and circumstances in which an emotional memory was first formed
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Long-term potentiation (LTP)}} is a long-lasting strengthening of synapses between nerve cells

Psychologists use LTP to explain long-term memories


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Synaptic plasticity}} is change that occurs at synapses, the junctions between neurons that allow them to communicate
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::decay theory::... theory}} proposes that memory fades due to the mere passage of time
Khan Academy Link
If you forget something, you can relearn it and the second time around the learning will be faster. This is called the {{c1::savings effect::... effect}}

This means that some foundation of the memory still exists even if you "completely forget" something


Khan Academy Link

A/an {{c1::prospective memory::... memory}} has the function of reminding yourself to remember something in the future. It may be defined as “remembering to remember” or remembering to perform an intended action
Wernicke's encephalopathy is a degenerative brain disorder caused by the lack of thiamine (vitamin B1) and is a precursor to {{c1::Korsakoff's Syndrome}}
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::cognitive economy principle::... principle}} is a principal that refers to the simplicity and relevance of a cognitive categorization scheme or representation
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::modified semantic network model::... model}} states that every individual semantic network develops based on experience and knowledge with no required hierarchical order
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::spreading activation model::... model}} states that all the ideas in our brain are connected together and when we recall one memory, another memory is recalled with it

Example: saying "fire engine" activates the words truck, fire, and red which makes it easier to identify/retrieve those items


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Well-defined problems::... problems}} have specific goals, clearly defined solution paths, and clear expected solutions
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Ill-defined problems::... problems}} are those that do not have clear goals, solution paths, or expected solution
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Trial and error}} is a fundamental method of problem solving that is characterized by repeated, varied attempts which are continued until success, or until the agent stops trying
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::algorithm}} is a clearly defined set of instructions to solve a problem
Khan Academy Link
In a/an {{c1::means-ends analysis}}, one solves a problem by considering the obstacles that stand between the initial problem state and the goal state
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Intuition}} is receiving input and ideas without knowing exactly how and where you got them from
Khan Academy Link
In problem solving, the term {{c1::fixation}} refers to the inability to see a problem from a fresh perspective
Khan Academy Link
In problem solving, {{c1::incubation}} is when you set a problem aside for a while
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::conjunction fallacy}} occurs when it is assumed that multiple specific conditions are more probable than a single general one

The probability that Linda is both a bank teller and something else (active in the feminist movement) must be lower, because there is a smaller number of people who are bank tellers and are active in the feminist movement than there are people who are bank tellers


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::anchoring and adjustment heuristic::... heuristic}} is when people start with an implicitly suggested reference point (the "anchor") and then make adjustments to it to reach their estimate
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Belief perseverance}} is maintaining a belief despite new information that firmly contradicts it
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Framing bias::... bias}} occurs when people make a decision based on the way the information is presented, as opposed to just on the facts themselves
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::intelligence quotient (IQ)}} is a score derived from several standardized tests designed to assess human intelligence
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::general intelligence theory::... theory}} states that an underlying factor of general intelligence exists and it forms the foundation out of which all intellectual abilities rise

This factor is referred to as the "G-factor"


Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Emotional intelligence}} is the ability to monitor one's own and other people's emotions, to discriminate between different emotions and label them appropriately, and to use emotional information to guide thinking and behavior
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Fluid intelligence}} is the capacity to think logically and solve problems in novel situations, independent of acquired knowledge

Fluid intelligence involves the ability to identify patterns and relationships that underpin novel problems and to extrapolate these findings using logic


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Crystallized intelligence}} is defined as the ability to use learned knowledge and experience

Fluid intelligence involves the ability to identify patterns and relationships that underpin novel problems and to extrapolate these findings using logic


Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::Stanford-Binet intelligence scales}} are designed to measure five factors of cognitive ability, including fluid reasoning, knowledge, quantitative reasoning, visual-spatial processing and working memory

Theoretically then the Stanford-Binet test measures a person's ability to learn


Khan Academy Link

The nature vs nurture debate involves the way a person's behavior develops. The terms nature and nurture refer to:

Nature: {{c1::genes and hereditary factors}}

Nurture: {{c1::environmental variables}}
Khan Academy Link
In a {{c1::fixed mindset::... mindset}}, people believe their basic qualities, like their intelligence or talent, are simply fixed traits
Khan Academy Link
In a {{c1::growth mindset::... mindset}}, people believe that their most basic abilities can be developed through dedication and hard work
Khan Academy Link
Galton’s idea of hereditary genius is one that considers both mental and physical features to be {{c1::inherited}}
YouTube Link
{{c1::Mental age}} is a measure of an individual's mental attainment based on the age in which it takes an average individual to reach that same level of attainment
YouTube Link

{{c1::Convergent intelligence}} means the ability to give the "correct" answer to standard questions that do not require significant creativity, for instance in most tasks in school and on standardized multiple-choice tests for intelligence

It is the opposite of divergent thinking



YouTube Link
The theory of {{c1::primary mental abilities}} states that intelligent behavior emerges from 7 independent factors called primary abilities

Word fluency
Verbal comprehension
Spatial visualization
Number facility
Associative memory
Reasoning
Perceptual speed


Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::triarchic theory of intelligence::theory}} describes three distinct types of intelligence that a person can possess: 

Analytical (componential)
Creative (experiential)
Practical (contextual)
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Apraxia}} is a motor disorder caused by damage to the brain in which the individual has difficulty with the motor planning to perform tasks or movements when asked

{{c1::Childhood apraxia of speech (CAS)}} is a speech disorder in which a child's brain has difficulty coordinating the complex oral movements needed to create sounds into syllables, syllables into words, and words into phrases
Typically, muscle weakness is not to blame for this speech disorder
{{c1::Global aphasia}} is a type of aphasia that results when damage in the brain is extensive enough to involve both the Broca's and Wernicke's language areas

Survivors with global aphasia are unable to understand spoken language or to speak


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Agraphia}} is an acquired neurological disorder causing a loss in the ability to communicate through writing, either due to some form of motor dysfunction or an inability to spell
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Alexia (or dyslexia)}} is defined as an acquired impairment affecting reading ability
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Anomia}} is a form of aphasia in which the individual struggles to find the right words to speak
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::corpus callosum}} is a thick band of nerve fibers that divides the cerebral cortex lobes into left and right hemispheres

It connects the left and right sides of the brain allowing for communication between both hemispheres


Khan Academy Link
Dysfunction or absence of the {{c1::corpus callosum}} can result in a condition known as split-brain syndrome, in which each hemisphere of the brain functions independently
Khan Academy Link
The hemispheres of the brain control the {{c1::contralateral}} sides of the body
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Prosody}} is an important element of language that contributes toward rhythmic and acoustic effects in a piece of writing

Prosody may reflect the speaker's sense of irony or sarcasm


Khan Academy Link
A {{c1::linguistic universal}} is a pattern that occurs systematically across natural languages

For example, all languages have nouns and verbs, or If a language is spoken, it has consonants and vowels


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::linguistic universalism theory::theory}} states that humans share a kind of “psychic unity”.  Language is merely a reflection of human thought and nothing more

Example: The New Guinea people only think about dark and light

If they had other thoughts, they would develop words for them


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Linguistic determinism}} is the idea that language and its structures limit and determine human knowledge or thought
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Strong linguistic determinism}}, also known as {{c1::Sapir-Whorfian hypothesis}}, states that language determines thought completely

This is the opposite of relativism which states that language influences thought only partly


Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::critical period}} and {{c1::sensitive period}} are maturational stages in the lifespan of an organism during which the nervous system is especially sensitive to certain environmental stimuli

"Critical period" also relates to the ability to acquire one's first language


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Transformationalist grammar}}: refers to the different ways that words can be arranged to convey the same information
{{c1::Lexicon}} refers to the list of words along with its related knowledge on their linguistic significance and usage
Vocabulary merely means the list of words a person knows
{{c1::Lexical access}} refers to identifying a word and connecting it to its meaning, which has been stored in long-term memory
{{c1::Klüver–Bucy syndrome}} is a syndrome resulting from bilateral lesions of the medial temporal lobe

Symptoms include compulsive eating, hypersexuality, insertion of inappropriate objects in the mouth (hyperorality), visual agnosia, and docility


Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::Lazarus theory of emotion::theory of emotion}} states that our experience of emotion depends on how the situation is cognitively appraised (labelled) and that label is based on cultural and individual differences
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::Yerkes-Dodson law::... law}} suggests that there is a relationship between performance and arousal. Increased arousal can help improve performance, but only up to a certain point
YouTube Link
{{c1::Complex emotions::... emotions}}, such as grief, regret and jealousy, have <u>highly variable appearances and compositions</u>
Basic emotions, which include sadness, anger, fear, disgust, contempt, joy, and surprise, are so-called because they are associated with {{c1::universally recognizable facial expressions}}
Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::dimensional approach::... approach}} to emotion refers to how people experience their emotions. Emotions are measured in terms of dimensions such as arousal (high/low) and valence (positive/negative)
As opposed to discrete emotion theory which is the claim that there is a small number of core emotions
{{c1::Discrete emotion theory::Theory}} is the claim that there is a small number of core, discreet, emotions
{{c1::Moods}} typically last longer than emotions

Moods are more generalized than emotions



YouTube Link
The quicker you are able to switch or “shift” your thinking from one dimension (e.g. color of an object) to another (e.g. shape of an object), the greater your level of {{c1::cognitive flexibility}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Coping}} refers to efforts to manage stress
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Adaptive}} coping strategies generally involve confronting problems directly, making reasonably realistic appraisals of problems, recognizing and changing unhealthy emotional reactions, and trying to prevent adverse effects on the body
{{c1::Maladaptive}} coping strategies relieve symptoms temporarily but don't address the root cause of the stress
While adaptive coping methods improve functioning, a maladaptive coping technique will just reduce symptoms and maintain or strengthen the disorder
{{c1::Meaning-focused}} coping involves searching for meaning in adversity and drawing on values, beliefs, and goals to modify the meaning given to and personal response to a stressful situation
{{c1::Low-effort syndrome::... syndrome}} or {{c1::low-effort coping::... coping}} refers to the coping responses of minority groups in an attempt to fit into the dominant culture
For example, minority students at school may learn to put in only minimal effort as they believe they are being discriminated against by the dominant culture
The {{c1::old brain}} regulates basic survival functions, such as breathing, moving, resting, feeding, emotions, and memory

Includes: 

Brain stem
Medulla
Pons
Reticular formation
Thalamus
Cerebellum
Amygdala
Hypothalamus
Hippocampus


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::cerebellum::brain structure}} receives information from the sensory systems, the spinal cord, and other parts of the brain and then regulates motor movements
Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::brainstem}} controls the flow of messages between the brain and the rest of the body, and it also controls basic body functions such as breathing, swallowing, heartrate, blood pressure, consciousness, and whether one is awake or sleepy
Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::reticular formation::brain structure}} is a portion of the brain that is located in the central core of the brain stem. Its functions include motor control, sensory control, visceral control, and control of consciousness
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Cranial nerves::... nerves}} arise from the brain and are distributed in the head, neck, and facial regions areas whereas
YouTube Link
{{c1::Spinal nerves::... nerves}} arise from the spinal cord and are distributed in the other parts of the body such as the skin, skeletal muscles, and blood vessels
YouTube Link
The {{c1::pons::brain structure}} is a major structure in the upper part of your brainstem. It regulates waking and relaxing
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Phrenology}} is a pseudoscience which involves the measurement of bumps on the skull to predict mental traits

It is based on the concept that the brain is the organ of the mind, and that certain brain areas have localized, specific functions or modules


Khan Academy Link
People with brain lesions are often the subjects of research with the goal of establishing the function of the area where their lesion occurred. This is called a {{c1::lesion study}}
Khan Academy Link

A {{c1::CT scan}} or {{c1::computed tomography scan}} makes use of computer-processed combinations of many X-ray measurements taken from different angles to produce cross-sectional images of specific areas of a scanned object, allowing the user to see inside the object without cutting
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)}} uses strong magnetic fields, magnetic field gradients, and radio waves to generate images of the organs in the body

An MRI studies the water molecule's hydrogen nuclei whereas an fMRI calculates the levels of oxygen


Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::electroencephalogram (EEG)}} is a test that detects electrical activity in your brain using small, metal discs (electrodes) attached to your scalp
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI)}} measures the small changes in blood flow that occur with brain activity

An MRI studies the water molecule's hydrogen nuclei whereas an fMRI calculates the levels of oxygen


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Positron emission tomography (PET)}} scan is an imaging test that helps reveal how your tissues and organs are functioning

A PET scan uses a radioactive drug (tracer) to show this activity


Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Acquired traits::... traits}} are learned and from
experience with a person’s environment
YouTub Link
{{c1::Temperament}} refers to personality traits that determine how someone reacts to the world

More broad than personality

The traits of temperament are mostly innate traits that we are born with, although they can be influenced by an individual's family, culture or their experiences


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Personality}} is the unique combination of patterns that influence behavior, thought, motivation, and emotion in a human being
Khan Academy Link

Twin studies are studies conducted on identical or fraternal twins with the aim of revealing the importance of {{c1::environmental}} and {{c1::genetic}} influences for traits, phenotypes, and disorders

Problem: Identical twins tend to be treated more similarly than fraternal twins are. This would mean that monozygotic twins share even more of same environments than fraternal twins


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Epigenetics}} is the term used to describe inheritance by mechanisms other than through the DNA sequence of genes

For example, enviromental factors that may affect our DNA


YouTube Link
{{c1::Ethology}} is the scientific and objective study of behaviour, usually with a focus on behaviour under natural conditions, and viewing behaviour as an evolutionarily adaptive trait
Khan Acaemy Link
{{c1::Comparative psychology}} is the study of animals in order to find out about humans
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Innate}} behaviors do not have to be learned or practiced. An animal can perform the behavior the first time it is exposed to the proper stimulus
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::fixed-action pattern (FAP)}} is a sequence of innate coordinated movements performed without interruption. Similar to a reflex, but more complicated
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Covert behavior::... behavior}} is behavior that is not observable
{{c1::Amotivation}} is a state of lacking any motivation to engage in an activity

The sexual response cycle has four phases: 

{{c1::Excitement}}
{{c1::Plateau}}
{{c1::Orgasm}}
{{c1::Resolution}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Prolactin::Hormone}} is related to sexual gratification and is associated with relieving sexual arousal after an orgasm
{{c1::Endorphins}} produce feelings of euphoria and pleasure, and are released post-orgasm
{{c1::Oxytocin::Hormone}} is released after an orgasm to facilitate bonds and feelings of connectedness between sexual partners

The {{c1::theory of planned behavior::theory}} states that we consider our implications of our actions before we decide on how to behave. The best predictor of our behavior is the strength of these intensions and implications

Subjective norms are what we think others think about our behavior

Perceived behavioral control is how easy/hard we think it is to control our behavior


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::attitude to behavior process model::... model}} states that behaviors stem from individuals' perceptions of an attitude object and a situation in which the attitude object is encountered
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::prototype willingness model}} assumes that the evaluation (attractiveness or unattractiveness) of the risk prototype shapes willingness to engage in the behavior
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::foot-in-the-door technique::... technique}} is when a small request is initially made in order to get a person to later agree to a bigger request
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Effort justification}} is people's tendency to attribute a greater value (greater than the objective value) to an outcome if they had to put effort into acquiring or achieving it
When you say "no" to a large demand, only to subsequently agree to a smaller demand, this is called the {{c1::door in the face technique::... technique}}
YouTube Link
{{c1::Cognitive dissonance}} is the mental discomfort experienced by a person who holds two or more contradictory beliefs, ideas, or values

This discomfort is triggered by a situation in which a person’s belief clashes with new evidence perceived by the person



Khan Academy Link

There are four things we do to reduce cognitive dissonance:

{{c1::Attitude change}}
{{c1::Behavior change}}
{{c1::Perceptual change}}
{{c1::Attribution change}}
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::situational approach to behavior theory::... theory}} states that different situations demand different behavioral approaches
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Social psychology::... psychology}} studies how people act, think, and feel in the context of society
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Projection}} is a psychological defense mechanism in which individuals attribute characteristics they find unacceptable in themselves to another person
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Reaction formation}} is a kind of psychological defense mechanism in which a person perceives their true feelings or desires to be socially unacceptable, so they attempt to convince themselves or others that the opposite is true--often in a very exaggerated performance
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Regression}} is a defense mechanism in which we perform behaviors that as if we were at a much younger stage in our lives
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Sublimation}} is a mature type of defense mechanism, in which socially unacceptable impulses or idealizations are transformed into socially acceptable actions or behavior, possibly resulting in a long-term conversion of the initial impulse
Khan Academy Link
A {{c1::Freudian slip}}, also called parapraxis, is an error in speech, memory, or physical action that occurs due to the interference of an unconscious subdued wish or internal train of thought
Khan Academy Link

According to Hans Eysenck, {{c1::extraverts::introverts or extraverts}} seek excitement and social activity in an effort to heighten their arousal level, whereas {{c1::introverts::introverts or extraverts}} tend to avoid social situations in an effort to keep such arousal to a minimum
Khan Academy Link

In Jeffrey Alan Gray's {{c1::biopsychological theory}} of personality, a behavioral approach system (BAS) is believed to regulate appetitive motives, in which the goal is to move toward something desired. A behavioral avoidance (or inhibition) system (BIS) is said to regulate aversive motives, in which the goal is to move away from something unpleasant
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Social potency}} is defined as social dominance or interpersonal power and a desire to make an impact on others

MPQ = Multidimensional Personality Questionnaire

Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::dopamine receptor D4 (DRD4) gene::... gene}} is known to regulate traits such as motivation and thrill seeking, and is also associated with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and addictive and risky behavior
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Surface}} traits of personality are very obvious and can be easily identified by other people, whereas {{c1::source}} traits are less visible to other people and appear to underlie several differentaspects of behavior
YouTube Link

The {{c1::Myers–Briggs type indicator}} is an introspective self-report questionnaire with the purpose of indicating differing psychological preferences in how people perceive the world around them and make decisions
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Denial}} is the refusal to accept reality or fact and acting as if a painful event, thought or feeling did not exist
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Passive-aggressive}} behaviors are those that involve acting indirectly aggressive rather than directlyaggressive

Passive-aggressive people regularly exhibit resistance to requests or demands from family and other individuals often by procrastinating, expressing sullenness, or acting stubborn


Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Intellectualization}} is a defense mechanism by which reasoning is used to block confrontation with an unconscious conflict and its associated emotional stress – where thinking is used to avoid feeling
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Rationalization}} is a defense mechanism in which controversial behaviors or feelings are justified and explained in a seemingly rational or logical manner to avoid the true explanation
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Repression}} is a type of psychological defense mechanism that involves keeping certain thoughts, feelings, or urges out of conscious awareness
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Suppression}} involves denying impulses at a conscious level and {{c1::repression}} involves denying impulses at a subconscious level
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Displacement}} is a defense mechanism that involves taking out our frustrations, feelings, and impulses on people or objects that are less threatening
Khan Academy Link
In Freudian psychoanalysis, the {{c1::pleasure principle::... principle}} is the instinctive seeking of pleasure and avoiding of pain to satisfy biological and psychological needs

The reality and pleasure principle both fill the task of gratification


Khan Academy Link

In Freudian psychoanalysis, the {{c1::reality principle}} is the ability of the mind to assess the reality of the external world, and to act upon it accordingly, as opposed to acting on the pleasure principle

The reality and pleasure principle both fill the task of gratification

With the reality principle you might have to wait for gratification (may be a delay)


Khan Academy Link

Freud identifies two drives that both coincide and conflict within the individual and among individuals:

Eros is the drive of {{c1::life}}

Thanatos is the drive of {{c1::death}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Neustress}}, is a type of stress that is neither positive nor negative. It refers to events that have no actual impact on a person
{{c1::Neurodevelopmental disorders::... disorders}} are a group of disorders in which the development of the central nervous system is disturbed

Intellectual disability
Autism spectrum disorders
ADHD


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Neurocognitive disorders::... disorders}} are an acquired cognitive decline in one or more cognitive domains

Dementia


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Sleep disorders::... disorders}} involve problems with the quality, timing and amount of sleep, which cause problems with functioning and distress during the daytime
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Elimination disorders::... disorders}} are disorders that concern the elimination of urine or feces from the body at inappropriate times or places
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Sexual dysfunction}} refers to a problem occurring during any phase of the sexual response cycle that prevents the individual or couple from experiencing satisfaction from the sexual activity
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Gender dysphoria}} is the distress a person feels due to their birth-assigned sex and gender not matching their gender identity

People who experience gender dysphoria are typically transgender


Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Paraphilic disorders::... disorders}} are recurrent, intense, sexually arousing fantasies, urges, or behaviors that are distressing or disabling and that involve inanimate objects, children or nonconsenting adults, or suffering or humiliation of oneself or the partner with the potential to cause harm
Khan Academy Link
In medicine, a {{c1::prodrome}} is an early sign or symptom, which often indicate the onset of a disease before more diagnostically specific signs and symptoms develop

Example: schizophrenia prodromal symptoms include various mood changes such as anxiety, depression, mood swings, sleep disturbances, irritability, anger, and suicidal ideas


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Factitious disorder::... disorder}} is a mental disorder in which a person acts as if he or she has a physical or mental illness when, in fact, he or she has consciously created the symptoms
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Antisocial personality disorder::... disorder}} is a personality disorder characterized by a long term pattern of disregard for, or violation of, the rights of others

A low moral sense or conscience is often apparent, as well as a history of crime, legal problems, or impulsive and aggressive behavior


Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Borderline personality disorder::... disorder}} is a personality disorder that typically includes the following symptoms: inappropriate or extreme emotional reactions, highly impulsive behaviors, and a history of unstable relationships
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Histrionic personality disorder::... disorder}} is a personality disorder characterized by a pattern of excessive attention-seeking emotions, usually beginning in early adulthood, including inappropriately seductive behavior and an excessive need for approval
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Narcissistic personality disorder::... disorder}} is a personality disorder with a long-term pattern of abnormal behavior characterized by exaggerated feelings of self-importance, excessive need for admiration, and a lack of empathy
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Avoidant personality disorder::... disorder}} is characterized by feelings of extreme social inhibition, inadequacy, and sensitivity to negative criticism and rejection
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Dependent personality disorder::... disorder}} is an anxious personality disorder characterized by an inability to be alone

People with DPD develop symptoms of anxiety when they're not around others


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Sleep apnea}} is a potentially serious sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts

Cheyne–Stokes respiration is an abnormal pattern of breathing characterized by progressively deeper, and sometimes faster, breathing followed by a gradual decrease that results in a temporary stop in breathing called an apnea


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Lewy body dementia}} is a disease associated with abnormal deposits of a protein called alpha-synuclein in the brain

These deposits, called Lewy bodies, affect chemicals in the brain whose changes, in turn, can lead to problems with thinking, movement, behavior, and mood


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Cognitive distortions}} are ways that our mind convinces us of something that isn't really true

All-or-Nothing Thinking / Polarized Thinking
Overgeneralization
Mental Filter
Disqualifying the Positive
Jumping to Conclusions – Mind Reading
Jumping to Conclusions – Fortune Telling
Magnification (Catastrophizing) or Minimization
Emotional Reasoning
Should Statements
Labeling and Mislabeling
Personalization
Control Fallacies
Fallacy of Fairness
Fallacy of Change
Always Being Right
Heaven’s Reward Fallacy


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Informational social influence::... influence}} is where a person conforms to a group in order to gain knowledge, or because they believe that someone else is 'right'
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Normative social influence::... influence}} is where a person conforms with a group in order to be <u>liked and accepted by them</u>
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Compliance}} is the lowest level of conformity. Here a person changes their public behaviour but not their private beliefs
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Identification}} is the middle level of conformity. Here a person changes their public behaviour and their private beliefs, but only while they are in the presence of the group
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Internalization}} is the deepest level of conformity. Here a person changes their public behaviour and their private beliefs. This is usually a long-term change and often the result of informational social influence
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Labeling theory::... theory}} proposes deviance is socially constructed through reaction instead of action. According to this theory, no behavior is inherently deviant on its own
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Primary deviance::... deviance}} is deviance with no serious consequences. The person committing the act is not labeled as a deviant
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Secondary deviance::... deviance}} has serious consequences and is characterized by a severe negative reaction that produces a stigmatizing label which results in more deviant behavior
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Collective behavior}} refers to events that suddenly emerge. These events do not conform to rules or laws but instead are shaped based on the issue at hand
Khan Academy Link
A {{c1::fad}} is a type of collective behavior in which a group of people enthusiastically follow an impulse for a finite period
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Mass hysteria}} is a type of collective behavior that transmits illusions of threats, whether real or imaginary, through a population in society as a result of rumors and fear
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::riot}} is a violent form of crowd behavior that results from feelings of injustice or feeling that needs have been ignored
Khan Academy Link
Stimulus {{c1::generalization}} occurs when a person responds to a stimulus in the same way that he or she responds to a similar stimulus
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Spontaneous recovery}} refers to the re-emergence of a previously extinguished conditioned response after a delay
Khan Academy Link

A/an {{c1::extinction burst}} refers to one's reaction to a stimulus that used to produce positive reinforcements, but now ceases to exist. The reaction will increase in an attempt to bring the reward back
YouTube Link
{{c1::Aversive conditioning}} is the use of something unpleasant, or a punishment, to stop an unwanted behavior

{{c1::Systematic desensitization}} is a behavioral technique commonly used to treat fear, anxiety disorders and phobias. Using this method, the person is engaged in some type of relaxation exercise and gradually exposed to an anxiety-producing stimulus, like an object or place
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Counterconditioning}} involves the conditioning of an unwanted behavior or response to a stimulus into a wanted behavior or response by the association of positive actions with the stimulus
{{c1::Primary::Primary or Secondary}} reinforcers are biological. They occur naturally and do not need to be learned
YouTube Link
{{c1::Secondary::Primary or Secondary}} reinforcers are things we have learned have value. They can be used to obtain a primary reinforcer
YouTube Link
A/an {{c1::token economy}} is a system of behavior modification based on systematic reinforcement of target behavior. Reinforcers are “tokens” that can be exchanged for other reinforcers
YouTube Link
{{c1::Instinctive drift}} is the tendency of an animal to revert to instinctive behaviors that interfere with a conditioned response
The paradox of choice states that the more choices there are, the {{c1::less::more or less}} satisfied we become
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Self-control}}, an aspect of inhibitory control, is the ability to regulate one's emotions, thoughts, and behavior in the face of temptations and impulses
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Ego depletion}} refers to the idea that self-control or willpower draws upon a limited pool of mental resources that can be used up. When the energy for mental activity is low, self-control is typically impaired
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::existential}} self is the most basic part of our self-concept. It is the sense of being separate and distinct from others
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::categorical}} self is the ability to put the self into categories, such as age, gender, skill or size
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Sociocultural theory of development::Theory}} looks at the important contributions that society makes to individual development. This theory stresses the interaction between developing people and the culture in which they live
Khan Academy Link
The theory of {{c1::social behaviorism}} states that people develop self-images through interactions with other people. Our self-image is a product of social experience
Khan Academy Link
The looking-glass self theory suggests that our self-concept is influenced by {{c1::how we perceive that others are viewing us}}

Important to note: According to this theory, we are not actually being influenced by opinions of others, but what we imagine the opinions of other people to be


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::covariation model}} states that there are three types of causal information which influence our judgements: consensus, distinctiveness, and consistency
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Individualistic}} cultures prioritize the individual over the entire group. These cultures are oriented around the self, being independent instead of identifying with a group mentality

Western Europe and the United States


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Collectivistic}} cultures emphasize the needs and goals of the group as a whole over the needs and desires of each individual
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Optimism bias::... bias}} is belief bad things happen to others, but not to us
YouTube Link
The {{c1::frustration aggression hypothesis::... hypothesis}} states that aggression is the result of blocking, or frustrating, a person's efforts to attain a goal
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Scapegoating}} is the practice of singling out a person or group for unmerited blame and consequent negative treatment
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::just-world}} phenomenon is the tendency to believe that the world is just and that people get what they deserve
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::halo effect}} is a type of cognitive bias in which our overall impression of a person influences how we feel and think about his or her character

Essentially, your overall impression of a person ("He is nice!") impacts your evaluations of that person's specific traits ("He is also smart!")

Example: The physical attractiveness stereotype. We believe attractive people have more positive personality traits


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Ethnography}} is the systematic study of people and cultures
YouTube Link
{{c1::Xenocentrism}} is the preference for the products, styles, or ideas of someone else's culture rather than of one's own
{{c1::Cultural imperialism}} is the deliberate imposition of one’s own cultural values on another culture
The {{c1::mere-exposure effect::... effect}} is a psychological phenomenon by which people tend to develop a preference for things merely because they are familiar with them
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::false consensus effect::... effect}} occurs when we overestimate the number of other people (or extent to which other people) share our opinions, beliefs, and behaviors
YouTube Link
A/an {{c1::projection bias::... bias}} is when we assume other share the same beliefs we do
A/an {{c1::social script}} is a series of behaviors, actions, and consequences that are expected in a particular situation or environment
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Kin selection}} is the evolutionary strategy that favors the reproductive success of an animal's relatives, even at a cost to that animal's own survival
Khan Academy Link
Altruism among non-relatives is called {{c1::reciprocal}} altruism
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::costly signaling theory::... theory}} says that although costly, altruistic acts may benefit the altruist indirectly, by establishing a 'reputation'
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Companionship support::... support}} is the type of support that gives someone a sense of social belonging
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Institutionalized discrimination}} refers to the unjust and discriminatory mistreatment of an individual or group of individuals by society and its institutions as a whole
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Side effect discrimination}} is a rule or practice unintentionally singles out particular people and results in unfair treatment
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Past-in-present discrimination}} is discrimination from the past that is still affecting people today
Khan Academy Link

A {{c1::utilitarian organization::... organization}}, also known as a remunerative organization, is a group of individuals who join in order to receive a monetary reward or some other benefit that is offered to members of that organization
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Normative organizations::... organizations}} have voluntary membership based on shared goals and interests
Khan Academy Link
A prison is an example of a {{c1::coercive organization::... organization}}, which maintains control through force
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::McDonaldization}} of society is a phenomenon that occurs when society, its institutions, and its organizations are adapted to have the same characteristics that are found in fast food chains. These include efficiency, calculability, predictability and standardization and control
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Autocommunication}} is communication to oneself
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Anthropomorphism}} is the attribution of human traits, emotions, or intentions to non-human entities
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Random mating}} describes an ideal situation in which all individuals on one sex are equally potential partners of all members of the opposite sex

The technical term for it is panmixia

Random mating is one of the requirements for the Hardy–Weinberg law to hold true



Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Assortative mating}} is when individuals with similar phenotypes mate with one another more frequently than would be expected under a random mating pattern
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Evolutionary game theory::... theory}} is the application of game theory to evolving populations in biology. It defines a framework of contests, strategies, and analytics into which Darwinian competition can be modelled
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Hidden curriculum}} refers to the unwritten, unofficial, and often unintended lessons, values, and perspectives that students learn in school
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Secularization}} is the weakening of social and political power of religious organizations as religious involvement declines
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Fundamentalism}} is a reaction to secularization in which members of a religion develop strict religious beliefs
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::democracy}} is a form of government in which power is vested in the people and exercised directly by them or by their elected agents under a free electoral system
Khan Academy Link

A/an {{c1::dictatorship}} is an authoritarian form of government, characterized by a single leader or group of leaders with either no party or a weak party, little mass mobilization, and limited political pluralism
YouTube Link

{{c1::Communism}} is a form of government which advocates class warfare and leads to a society in which all property is publicly owned and each person's work is paid according to their abilities and needs
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::monarchy}} is the rule of a king, queen, or an emperor
YouTube Link
{{c1::Capitalism}} is an economic system based on the private ownership of the means of production and their operation for profit
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Socialism}} is an economic and political system where the ways of making a living (factories, offices, etc.) are owned by the workers who run them and the people who depend on them, meaning the value made belongs to the people who make it, instead of a group of private owners
YouTube Link

{{c1::Medicalization}} is the process by which conditions and problems come to be defined and treated as medical conditions, and thus become the subject of medical study, diagnosis, prevention, or treatment
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Sick-role behavior}} is the activity undertaken, for the purpose of getting well, by those who consider themselves ill
YouTube Link
{{c1::Social epidemiology}} is a branch of epidemiology that focuses particularly on the effects of social-structural factors on states of health
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::bourgeoisie}} is defined as the middle class, typically used with reference to feelings of materialism when describing the middle class
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::proletariat}} is defined as working-class people, or people who perform labor for money
Khan Academy Link
In social philosophy, {{c1::objectification}} is the act of treating a person, or sometimes an animal, as an object or a thing
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Patriarchy}} is a social system in which men hold primary power and predominate in roles of political leadership, moral authority, social privilege and control of property
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Baby boomers}} are those people born worldwide between 1946 and 1964, the time frame most commonly used to define them
Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::life course theory::... theory}} is a multidisciplinary approach to understanding the mental, physical and social health of individuals, which incorporates both life span and life stage concepts that determine the health trajectory
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Age stratification}} refers to the hierarchical ranking of people into age groups within a society. It could also be defined as a system of inequalities linked to age
Khan Academy Link
A {{c1::pluralistic society::... society}} accepts many different sorts of people, from different races, sexual orientations, cultures, and religions
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Agender}} refers to people who don't identify themselves with any particular gender
Khan Academy Link
A person who is {{c1::gender fluid}} prefers to remain flexible about their gender identity rather than committing to a single gender
YouTube Link
{{c1::Non-binary}}, also known as genderqueer, is a spectrum of gender identities that are not exclusively masculine or feminine‍ identities that are outside the gender binary
Khan Academy Link

A/an {{c1::gender role}} is a social role encompassing a range of behaviors and attitudes that are generally considered acceptable, appropriate, or desirable for people based on their actual or perceived sex
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Racial formation theory::... theory}} links social structure and stratification to common ideas and assumptions about race and racial categories
Khan Academy Link
The gender schema theory proposes that children learn gender roles from their {{c1::culture}}
YouTube Link
A/an {{c1::ghetto}}, is a part of a city in which members of a minority group live, typically as a result of social, legal, or economic pressure
Ghettos are often known for being more impoverished than other areas of the city
{{c1::Fecundity}} is the potential to reproduce and how much a single person can reproduce i.e. how many children a single woman can give birth to
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::mass society theory::... theory}} is the basic idea is that people who are socially isolated are especially vulnerable to the appeals of extremist movements
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Gatekeeping theory::... theory}} states that when an event occurs, someone has to decide whether and how to pass the information to another person, such as a friend, an official, or even a journalist
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Intersectional theory::... theory}} asserts that people are often disadvantaged by multiple sources of oppression: their race, class, gender identity, sexual orientation, religion, and other identity markers
Khan Academy Link

Amino acids are simple organic compounds containing both a/an {{c1::carboxyl (—COOH)}} group and a/an {{c1::amino (—NH2)}} group
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Glycine}} is the only amino acid that is not chiral
Khan Academy Link
The stereochemistry of the α-carbon in all eukaryotic amino acids (except glycine) is {{c1::L}}
YouTube Link
All chiral amino acids except cysteine have {{c1::(S)}} configuration
YouTube Link

L and D indicate {{c1::relative}} configuration

S and R indicate {{c1::absolute}} configuration
YouTube Link
Amphoteric molecules can act as either a/an {{c1::base}} or a/an {{c1::acid}}
YouTube Link
The pH at which half of the species is deprotonated is called the {{c1::pKa}}

[HA] = [A-]


Khan Academy Link
A <u>low</u> pH will cause amino acids to be {{c1::full protonated}}
YouTube Link
{{c1::Isoelectric point}} is the pH at which an amino acid is in zwitterion form

The charges cancel out to make a neutral molecule


Khan Academy Link
YouTube Link
A/an {{c1::zwitterion}} is when all charges cancel out, so the molecule is neutral
Khan Academy Link

YouTube Link
At the equivalence point of a titration, pH = {{c1::pI}}
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::1°::1°, 2°, 3°, or 4°}} structure of proteins is the linear sequence of amino acids in a peptide

Stabilized by peptide bonds



Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::2°::1°, 2°, 3°, or 4°}} structure of proteins is the local folding of neighboring amino acids including α-helices and β-pleated sheets

Stabilized by hydrogen bonding



Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::3°::1°, 2°, 3°, or 4°}} structure of proteins is the 3-D shape of a single polypeptide chain

Stabilized by hydrophobic interactions, acid-base interactions, hydrogen-bonds, and disulfide bonds



Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::4°::1°, 2°, 3°, or 4°}} structure of proteins is the interaction between peptides in proteins that contain multiple subunits

The 4° structure of hemoglobin:

Khan Academy Link
{{c1::α-helices}} are clockwise coils around a central axis and are a common {{c1::2°::1°, 2°, 3°, or 4°}} protein structure
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::β-pleated sheets}} are rippled strands that can be parallel or antiparallel and are a common {{c1::2°::1°, 2°, 3°, or 4°}} protein structure

Proline is typically found at the turns in β-pleated sheets


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Proline::Amino acid}} has a rigid cyclic structure and can interrupt 2° protein structure

Proline is "kinky"


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Denaturation}} is when a protein (or nucleic acid) loses its 4°, 3°, and 2° structures due to breaking non-covalent interactions
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::hydrophobic effect}} pushes hydrophobic R groups to the interior of a protein, which {{c1::increases::increases or decreases}} entropy of the surrounding water molecules

When multiple hydrophobic molecules are in water, the molecules group together spontaneously

The combined molecules have less surface area touching water so fewer water molecules are needed to interact with the hydrophobic surface

This means more water molecules can roam freely which is an increase in entropy


YouTube Link
{{c1::Disulfide bonds}} occur when <u>two cysteine molecules</u> are oxidized and create a covalent bond between their thiol groups

This forms cystine


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Conjugated proteins}} are complex proteins, such as hemoglobin, consisting of amino acids combined with other substances
A/an {{c1::prosthetic group}} is the attached molecule in a conjugated protein and can be a metal ion, vitamin, lipid, carbohydrate, or nucleic acid
YouTube Link
Peptide bonds link the {{c1::α-carboxyl group::... group}} of one amino acid to the {{c1::α-amino group::... group}} of the next amino acid
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Enzymes}} are reusable catalysts that are unchanged by the reactions they catalyze

Catalyze both the forward and reverse reactions



Khan Academy Link
Exergonic reactions {{c1::release::require or release}} energy

-∆G 


Khan Academy Link
<u>Endergonic</u> reactions {{c1::require::require or release}} energy

+∆G


Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::oxidoreductase::type of enzyme}} catalyzes REDOX reactions that involve the transfer of electrons
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::transferase::type of enzyme}} moves a functional group from one molecule to another
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::hydrolase::type of enzyme}} catalyzes cleavage <u>with the addition of H<sub>2</sub>O</u>
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::lyase::type of enzyme}} catalyzes cleavage without the addition of H2O and without the transfer of electrons
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::isomerase::type of enzyme}} catalyzes the interconversion of isomers
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::ligase::type of enzyme}} joins two large biomolecules, often of the same type
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::lipase::type of enzyme}} catalyzes the hydrolysis of fats
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::kinase::type of enzyme}} adds a phosphate group from ATP to a substrate
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::phosphatase::type of enzyme}} <u>removes</u> a phosphate group
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::phosphorylase::type of enzyme}} adds a phosphate group from an inorganic phosphate like HPO4 to a substrate
YouTube Link
A Michaelis-Menten curve is {{c1::hyperbolic::shape}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Km}} is the substrate concentration that gives you a reaction rate that is halfway to Vmax
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Vmax}} is the maximum rate at which an enzyme can catalyze a reaction

This is when all enzyme active sites are saturated with substrate


Khan Academy Link

The Michaelis–Menten equation is:

{{c1::}}
Khan Academy Link
Cooperative enzymes display a {{c1::sigmoidal::shape}} curve

Sigmoidal because of the change in activity following initial substrate binding


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Cooperative binding}} is when the binding of the first molecule of B to A changes the binding affinity of the second B molecule, making it more or less likely to bind

Results in a sigmoidal curve


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::active site::part of enzyme}} is the site of catalysis
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::lock and key theory::... theory}} states that the enzyme and substrate are <u>exactly complementary</u> and fit together like a key into a lock
YouTube Link
The {{c1::induced fit theory::... theory}} states that the enzyme and substrate undergo conformational changes in order to interact fully
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::cofactor}} is a metal cation that is required by some enzymes
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::cofactor or coenzyme}} is an organic molecule that is required by some enzymes
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Feedback inhibition::... inhibition}} of an enzyme is when an enzyme is inhibited by high levels of a product from later in the same pathway
YouTube Link
A/an {{c1::competitive inhibitor::... inhibitor}} binds at the active site and thus prevents the substrate from binding

The ETC creates a {{c1::proton concentration gradient}} that is used to power ATP synthase

Protons are pumped into the intermembrane space so the concentration gradient is across the inner mitochondrial membrane


YouTube Link
Complex I in the ETC is also known as {{c1::NADH dehydrogenase}}

Complex I removes hydrogen from NADH to form NAD+

It is also called NADH Oxidoreductase because when the hydrogen is removed from NADH, electrons are removed with it which makes this a REDOX reaction



YouTube Link
<u>Complex II</u> in the ETC is also known as {{c1::succinate dehydrogenase}}

Complex II removes two hydrogens from succinate and adds them to FAD to make FADH2

The result is, succinate is oxidized to fumarate and FAD is reduced to FADH2

FADH2 is then oxidized back to FAD



YouTube Link
Complex III in the ETC is also known as {{c1::cytochrome reductase}}

Cytochrome is reduced



YouTube Link
Complex IV in the ETC is also known as {{c1::cytochrome oxidase}}

Cytochrome is oxidized as it reduces O2 to H2O



YouTube Link
{{c1::ATP synthase::Enzyme}} uses a proton gradient to power the conversion of ADP to ATP

<u>Complex II</u> in the ETC oxidizes {{c1::succinate}} to form {{c1::fumarate}}

Complex II directly receives FADH2, which does not pass through complex I



YouTube Link
ETC <u>complex II</u> {{c1::is not::is or is not}} a proton pump

Since complex II uses FADH2, but is not a proton pump, that means less ATP is formed from FADH2 compared to NADH



YouTube Link
ETC <u>Complex II</u> removes 2 hydrogens from {{c1::succinate}} and adds them to {{c1::FAD}}

FADH2 is then reduced back to FAD

Fatty acid synthesis includes the following 5 steps:

1. {{c1::Attach}}
2. {{c1::Condense}}
3. {{c1::Reduce}}
4. {{c1::Dehydration}}
5. {{c1::Reduce}}

ACR DR mnemonic

This adds two new carbon atoms to a fatty acid chain



YouTube Link
Fatty acid synthesis begins with the transfer of {{c1::acetyl-CoA}} from the mitochondria to the cytosol via the {{c1::citrate shuttle}}
YouTube Link
Fatty acid synthesis begins with the transfer of acetyl-CoA from the {{c1::mitochondria::cell part}} to the {{c1::cytosol::cell part}} via the citrate shuttle
YouTube Link
During the initiation of fatty acid synthesis, acetyl-CoA is activated through the synthesis of {{c1::malonyl-CoA}}
YouTube Link
The regulatory enzyme for fatty acid synthesis is {{c1::acetyl-CoA carboxylase}}

It activates acetyl-CoA



YouTube Link
The first step of fatty acid synthesis is 1: {{c1::Attach}}

Acetyl-CoA attaches to acyl carrier protein


YouTube Link
The second step of fatty acid synthesis is 2: {{c1::Condense}}

Malonyl-CoA condenses with acetyl-CoA, kicking off a CoA and CO2


YouTube Link
The third step of fatty acid synthesis is 3: {{c1::Reduce}}

NADPH reduces C=O to C-OH 


YouTube Link
The fourth step of fatty acid synthesis is 4: {{c1::Dehydration}}

The -OH group is removed through dehydration which produces a water molecule

This leaves behind a C=C double bond


YouTube Link
The fifth step of fatty acid synthesis is 5: {{c1::Reduce}}

NADPH reduces the double bond to make it a single bond

This completes the process of adding 2 new carbon atoms to the fatty acid chain


YouTube Link
Fatty acid synthesis occurs in the {{c1::cytosol::part of cell}}

{{c1::Beta oxidation}} is the process by which <u>fatty acids are oxidized and broken down</u>

It generates multiple molecules of 2 carbon Acetyl-CoA, plus the electron carriers NADH and FADH2


YouTube Link
<u>Beta oxidation</u> occurs in the {{c1::mitochondrial matrix::part of cell}}
YouTube Link
Acyl-CoA must use the {{c1::carnitine shuttle}} to pass through the inner mitochondrial membrane

Acyl-CoA can pass through porins in the outer membrane, but it needs the assistance of carnitine in order to move through the inner membrane


YouTube Link
Beta oxidation starts with the oxidation of {{c1::acyl-CoA}}
YouTube Link
The first step of beta oxidation is a/an {{c1::oxidation}}

Two hydrogens are removed from Acyl-CoA and donated to FAD

This means acyl-CoA is oxidized and FAD is reduced to FADH2


YouTube Link
The second step of beta oxidation is a/an {{c1::hydration}}

Water is added

-OH is added to the β carbon and -H is added to the α carbon


YouTube Link
The third step in beta oxidation is a/an {{c1::oxidation}}

A hydrogen is removed and donated to NAD+

This means NAD+ is reduced to NADH


YouTube Link
The fourth step of beta oxidation is a/an {{c1::thiolysis}}

The acyl-CoA undergoes thiolytic cleavage of the thioester

An acetyl-CoA molecule is broken off of the acyl-CoA


YouTube Link
The two main products of beta oxidation are {{c1::acetyl-CoA}} and {{c1::acyl-CoA}}

Acetyl-CoA is sent to the citric acid cycle

Acyl-CoA is now 2 carbons shorter than before the round of beta oxidation started


YouTube Link

A C16 fatty acid will undergo a maximum of {{c1::7::#}} rounds of beta oxidation

A C16 fatty acid that undergoes complete beta oxidation will produce {{c1::7::#}} NADH and {{c1::7::#}} FADH2

This is because a C16 fatty acid undergoes 7 rounds of beta oxidation and each round produces 1 NADH and 1 FADH2

Gel electrophoresis is a technique commonly used in laboratories to separate charged molecules like DNA, RNA and proteins according to their {{c1::size}} and {{c1::charge}}

Small molecules move fast

Large molecules move slow


Khan Academy Link

In gel electrophoresis:

Small molecules move {{c1::fast::fast or slow}}

Large molecules move {{c1::slow::fast or slow}}

Shorter molecules migrate more easily through the pores of the gel


Khan Academy Link

In gel electrophoresis:

{{c1::Agarose}} gel has large pores so it is used to separate nucleic acids

{{c1::Polyacrylamide}} gel has small pores so it is better for separating proteins

Nucleic acids are usually larger than proteins


Khan Academy Link
Native-PAGE is a polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis method for proteins using {{c1::non-denaturing::denaturing or non-denaturing}} conditions

YouTube Link
In SDS-PAGE, you can add an additional reducing agent called {{c1::2-mercaptoethanol}} to reduce disulfide bonds. This further denatures the protein
In isoelectric focusing, the gel has a pH gradient and the proteins will migrate through the gel until they reach the pH that matches their {{c1::isoelectric point}}

At the pI, the protein has a neutral charge, so it will no longer be attracted to the anode or the cathode and it will stop migrating


YouTube Link

{{c1::3::amount}} Na+ {{c1::out of::direction}} the cell
{{c1::2::amount}} K+ {{c1::into::direction}} the cell

Mnemonic:
3-2-1 NOKIA
3 Na+ Out

When one O2 molecule binds to one of the four heme groups in a hemoglobin, it becomes more likely that the remaining sites will bind to O2

CO2 and H+ allosterically inhibit hemoglobin

Khan Academy Link
A low pH means a {{c1::low::high or low}} heme affinity for O2

H+ is an inhibitor of heme, so it causes the heme to release its O2

This is called the Bohr Shift. The oxygen saturation curve will shift right in response to a low pH (high H+ concentration)

2,3-BPG causes heme to {{c1::release}} O2
