{{c1::Meissner's corpuscle}} is a type of nerve ending in the skin that is responsible for sensitivity to light touch
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Ruffini endings}} are responsible for the sensation of the stretch of your skin
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Pacinian corpuscles}} are nerve endings in the skin responsible for sensitivity to vibration and pressure
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Hypodermis}} lies between the dermis and underlying tissues and organs. It consists of mostly adipose tissue and is the storage site of most body fat
YouTube Link

Thermoregulation is accomplished through:

{{c1::Sweating}}
{{c1::Piloerection}}
{{c1::Shivering}}
{{c1::Vasodilation / Vasoconstriction}}
Khan Academy Link
Evaporation of sweat from the skin surface has a <u>cooling effect</u> due to {{c1::evaporative cooling}}

As each drop of sweat evaporates, it takes a bit of body heat away with it


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Piloerection}} is the erection or bristling of hairs due to the involuntary contraction of small muscles at the base of hair follicles that occurs as a reflexive response cold
YouTube Link
Shivering is when your {{c1::skeletal::type}} muscles shake in small movements. This creates warmth by expending energy
Khan Academy Link
Shrinking the diameter of blood vessels that supply the skin, a process known as vasoconstriction, reduces blood flow and helps {{c1::retain::expel or retain}} heat
Khan Academy Link
Vasodilation increases blood flow to the skin and helps to {{c1::expel::expel or retain}} heat
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Skeletal::Type}} muscle provides support and is involved with movement, blood propulsion, and thermoregulation
Khan Academy Link
<u>Skeletal </u>muscle {{c1::is::is or is not}} striated
Khan Academy Link
Striated muscle tissue is a muscle tissue that features repeating functional units called {{c1::sarcomeres}}
Khan Academy Link
Skeletal muscle is under {{c1::voluntary (somatic)::voluntary or involuntary}} control
Khan Academy Link
<u>Skeletal</u> muscle is {{c1::multinucleated::nucleation}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Antagonistic}} muscle pairs are those whose actions oppose each other
YouTube Link
{{c1::Red::Color}} skeletal muscle fibers are slow-twitch and carry out oxidative phosphorylation

The red color is from myoglobin, which binds oxygen


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::White::Color}} skeletal muscle fibers are fast-twitch and carry out anaerobic metabolism
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Smooth::Type}} muscle forms the supporting tissue of blood vessels and hollow internal organs, such as the stomach, intestine, and bladder
Khan Academy Link
Smooth muscle is considered smooth because {{c1::it does not have the striations }}
Khan Academy Link
Smooth muscle is under {{c1::involuntary (autonomic)::voluntary or involuntary}} control
Khan Academy Link
Smooth muscle is {{c1::uninucleated::nucleation}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Cardiac::Type}} muscle is an involuntary, striated muscle that constitutes the main tissue of the walls of the heart
Khan Academy Link
Cardiac muscle is under {{c1::involuntary (autonomic)::voluntary or involuntary}} control
Khan Academy Link
Cardiac muscle is {{c1::uninucelated::nucleation}}

It can sometimes be considered binucleated


Khan Academy Link
Cardiac muscle cells are connected with {{c1::intercalated discs}} that contain {{c1::gap junctions}}
Khan Academy Link
The skeletal system is derived from the {{c1::mesoderm::germ layer}}
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::axial skeleton::... skeleton}} includes the skull, vertebral column, ribcage, and hyoid bone
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::appendicular skeleton::... skeleton}} includes the limbs, pectoral girdle, and pelvis
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Compact}} bone, also known as cortical bone, is a dense material used to create much of the hard structure of the skeleton
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Spongy}} bone, also known as cancellous bone or trabecular bone, is a very porous type of bone located at the ends of the long bones (the epiphyses), with harder compact bone surrounding it
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Periosteum}} is a thin membrane that covers many of the bones in your body
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Bone marrow}} produces the cellular elements of the blood, including platelets, red blood cells and white blood cells
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Long bones::... bones}} are hard, dense bones that provide strength, structure, and mobility

Some bones in the fingers are classified as long bones, even though they are short in length


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Ligaments}} attach bones to other bones
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Tendons}} attach bones to muscles
Khan Academy Link
Bone tissue is also known {{c1::osseous}} tissue
YouTube Link
{{c1::Osteon}} is the chief structural unit of compact (cortical) bone

Consist of concentric bone layers called lamellae, which surround a long hollow passageway, the Haversian canal


Khan Academy Link
<u>Osteon</u> consist of concentric bone layers called {{c1::lamellae}}
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::haversian canals}} surround blood vessels and nerve cells throughout bones and communicate with bone cells through connections called canaliculi
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::canaliculi}} are small channels that link together the lacunae in bones
Khan Academy Link

Osteoblasts {{c1::build::build or resorb}} bone

Osteoclasts {{c1::resorb::build or resorb}} bone
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Cartilage}} is a connective tissue that is firm but flexible and connects bones together
Khan Academy Link
Cartilage is {{c1::avascular}} and {{c1::aneural}}

Avascular = no blood vessels

Aneural= no nerves


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Immovable}} joints are fused together to form sutures
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Movable}} joints are strengthened by ligaments and contain a synovial capsule
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Synovial}} fluid lubricates the joints and permits smooth movement
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Ossification}} is the process of laying down new bone material by cells called osteoblasts
YouTube Link
{{c1::Sarcomeres}} are the functional units of muscle and are composed of long, fibrous proteins as filaments that slide past each other when a muscle contracts or relaxes
Khan Academy Link
Two of the important proteins in a sarcomere are {{c1::myosin}}, which forms the thick filament, and {{c1::actin}}, which forms the thin filament
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Troponin::Protein}} is attached to the protein {{c1::tropomyosin::protein}} and the two regulate actin-myosin interactions
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Z-lines}} define the boundary of each sarcomere
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::M-line}} is the middle of a sarcomere
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::I-band}} is a light band on each side of the Z line comprising a region of the sarcomere where thin (actin) filaments are not overlapped by thick (myosin) filaments
Khan Academy Link
The H-zone contains only {{c1::myosin}} filaments
Khan Academy Link
The A-band contains both actin and myosin. It is the only part that {{c1::maintains a constant size during contraction}}
Khan Academy Link
Sarcomeres attached end-to-end to become {{c1::myofibrils}}
Khan Academy Link
Each {{c1::myocyte}} contains many myofibrils
YouTube Link
The {{c1::sarcoplasmic reticulum}} forms a cufflike structure surrounding a myofibril and its main function is to store Ca2+
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::sarcolemma}} is a cell membrane that encloses each muscle cell
Khan Academy Link
The sarcolemma maintains a/an {{c1::membrane potential}} much like a neuron does
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Transverse tubules (T-tubules)}} are extensions of the cell membrane that penetrate into the center of skeletal and cardiac muscle cells
Khan Academy Link
Muscle contraction begins at the neuromuscular junction, where the efferent neuron releases {{c1::acetylcholine}} which binds to receptors on the sarcolemma and causes depolarization
Khan Academy Link
In muscle contraction, depolarization spreads down the sarcolemma to the T-tubules, triggering the release of {{c1::Ca2+}}
Khan Academy Link
During muscle contraction, Ca2+ binds to {{c1::troponin}}, causing a shift in tropomyosin and exposure of the myosin-binding sites on the actin filament
YouTube Link
During muscle contraction, shortening of the sarcomere occurs as myosin heads bind to the exposed sites on actin, forming {{c1::cross bridges}} and pulling the actin filament along the thick filament
YouTube Link
Muscles relax when {{c1::acetylcholine}} is degraded by {{c1::acetylcholinesterase}}, terminating the signal and allowing Ca2+ to return to the sarcoplasmic reticulum
YouTube Link
{{c1::ATP}} binds to the myosin head, allowing it to release from actin
YouTube Link
A/an {{c1::single twitch}} is when only one muscle fiber responds to a brief stimulus
YouTube Link
Frequency summation is the addition of {{c1::multiple simple twitches}} before the muscle has a chance to fully relax
YouTube Link
In muscles, {{c1::creatine phosphate}} is what adds a phosphate group to ADP, forming ATP
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::allele}} is a variant form of a gene located at the same position on a chromosome
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Dominant}} alleles only require one copy in order to be expressed
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Recessive}} alleles require two copies in order to be expressed
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Genotype}} is the combination of alleles one has at a given locus
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::homozygous}} genotype has two of the same alleles
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::heterozygous}} genotype has two different alleles
Khan Academy Link
A recessive allele is only expressed if an organism is {{c1::homozygous}} for that trait both alleles are recessive
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Phenotype}} is the observable manifestation of a genotype
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Complete dominance::... dominance}} is a form of dominance in heterozygous condition wherein the allele that is regarded as dominant completely masks the effect of the allele that is recessive
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Incomplete dominance::... dominance}} is a form of intermediate inheritance in which one allele for a specific trait is not completely expressed over its paired allele
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Codominance}} is in which both alleles are simultaneously expressed in the heterozygote
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Penetrance}} is the proportion of individuals carrying a particular variant of a gene that also express an associated trait
YouTube Link
{{c1::Variable expressivity}} is when a phenotype is expressed but to a different degree among individuals with the same genotype
YouTube Link
{{c1::Genetic leakage}} is when genes flow from one species to another via hybrid offspring

Example: zebra-horse


YouTube Link
{{c1::Genetic drift}} is when the composition of the gene pool changes as a result of chance
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::founder effect}} is the loss of genetic variation that occurs when a new population is established by a very small number of individuals

Inbreeding


Khan Academy Link

Give the 7 taxonomic ranks in order:

Most specific: {{c1::Species}}
               {{c1::Genus}}
               {{c1::Family}}
               {{c1::Order}}
               {{c1::Class}}
               {{c1::Phylum}}
     Broadest: {{c1::Kingdom}}

King Phillip Came Over From Great Spain


Khan Academy Link
Mendel's {{c1::law of independent assortment::law of ...}} states that the alleles of two (or more) different genes get sorted into gametes independently of one another
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Chromosomal mutations::... mutations}} are much larger than nucleotide mutations and affect whole segments of DNA
YouTube Link
{{c1::Deletion}} is a chromosomal mutation in which a large segment of DNA is lost
YouTube Link
{{c1::Duplication}} is a chromosomal mutation in which a segment of DNA is copied multiple times
YouTube Link
{{c1::Inversion}} is a chromosomal mutation in which a segment of DNA is reversed
YouTube Link
{{c1::Translocation}} is a chromosomal inversion in which a segment of DNA is swapped with a segment of DNA from another chromosome
YouTube Link
The Griffith experiment showed that bacteria can get DNA through a process called {{c1::transformation}}

Griffith experiment with mice (R strain safe, S strain deadly)


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::Avery-MacLeod-McCarty experiment::... experiment}}, built upon Griffith's experiment and showed that <u>DNA is what caused the bacterial transformation</u>

This brought us one step closer to proving that DNA holds our genetic material


Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::Hershey-Chase experiment::... experiment}} confirmed DNA is what contains genetic material
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::Punnett square}} is a square diagram that is used to predict the genotypes of a particular cross or breeding experiment
YouTube Link

A dihybrid cross, shown above, will result in the following phenotypic ratios:

Expressed AB: {{c1::9/16::.../16}}
Expressed Ab: {{c1::3/16::.../16}}
Expressed aB: {{c1::3/16::.../16}}
Expressed ab: {{c1::1/16::.../16}}

9:3:3:1

Dihybrid cross means a cross involving two traits and each parent organism is heterozygous for both of the traits.


YouTube Link
When two genes are close together on the same chromosome, they {{c1::do not assort independently}} and are said to be linked
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Recombination frequency}} is the likelihood of two alleles being separated during crossing over in meiosis
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::farther apart::closer together or farther apart}} two alleles are on the same chromosome, the more likely they are to assort independently
Khan Academy Link

Give the Hardy-Weinberg equation:

{{c1::P2 + 2Pq + q2 = 1}}
Khan Academy Link
The mechanism for evolution is {{c1::natural selection}}
Khan Academy Link

Several major ideas about evolution came together in the early 20th century to form the modern synthesis model of evolution, including {{c1::genetic variation}}, {{c1::natural selection}}, and {{c1::Mendelian inheritance}}
YouTube Link
The {{c1::punctuated equilibrium theory::... theory}} considers evolution to be a very slow process with intermittent rapid bursts of evolutionary activity
YouTube Link
{{c1::Stabilizing selection::... selection}} is a type of natural selection in which the population mean stabilizes on a particular non-extreme trait value
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Directional selection::... selection}} is a mode of natural selection in which one extreme phenotype is favored over other phenotypes, causing the allele frequency to shift over time in the direction of that phenotype
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::Disruptive selection::... selection}} will cause organisms with intermediate traits to reproduce less often, and will allow those organisms with extreme traits (multiple traits) to reproduce more often. This drives a population apart
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Adaptive radiation}} is the relatively fast evolution of many species from a single common ancestor

Adaptive radiation generally occurs when an organism enters a new area and different traits affect its survival


YouTube Link
The molecular clock model states that the degree of difference in the genome between two species is related to the {{c1::amount of time}} since the two species broke off from a common ancestor
YouTube Link
{{c1::Divergent evolution::... evolution}} is the process whereby groups from the same common ancestor evolve and accumulate differences, resulting in the formation of new species
YouTube Link
{{c1::Parallel evolution::... evolution}} is the independent evolution of similar traits, starting from a similar ancestral condition
YouTube Link

{{c1::Convergent evolution::... evolution}} is the process whereby organisms that are not closely related will independently evolve similar traits as a result of having to adapt to similar environments or ecological niches
YouTube Link
The {{c1::arachidonic acid pathway::... pathway}} is a central regulator of the inflammatory response

Arachidonic acid is the precursor to eicosanoids


YouTube Link
Skeletal muscle contraction is initiated by {{c1::lower::upper or lower}} motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem
Khan Academy Link
In neurological terms, {{c1::fasciculations}} are the spontaneous firing of a motor unit

With fasciculation, only one or few of these units fire

Fasciculations can be caused by something as simple as drinking too much caffeine


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Hypotonia}}, commonly known as floppy baby syndrome, is a state of low muscle tone
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Hyporeflexia}} refers to below normal or absent reflexes

It can be detected through the use of a reflex hammer

It is the opposite of hyperreflexia


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Hair follicle receptors}} send and receive nerve impulses to and from the brain when hair moves
When the {{c1::stretch reflex::... reflex}} is activated, the stretched muscles and the supporting muscles are contracted while the antagonist muscles are inhibited (relaxed)

The stretch reflex (myotatic reflex) is a muscle contraction in response to stretching within the muscle


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Muscle spindles}} are stretch receptors within the body of a muscle that primarily detect changes in the length of the muscle
Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::corticospinal tract::... tract}} is a white matter motor pathway starting at the cerebral cortex that terminates on lower motor neurons and interneurons in the spinal cord, controlling movements of the limbs and trunk
Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::corticobulbar tract::... tract}} is a two-neuron path which unites the cerebral cortex with the cranial nerve nuclei in the brainstem involved in motor functions (apart from the oculomotor nerve)
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Clonus}} is a series of involuntary, rhythmic, muscular contractions and relaxations
Khan Academy Link

In some patients, stroking the sole of the foot produces extension (dorsiflexion) of the big toe, often with extension and abduction ("fanning") of the other toes. This abnormal response is termed the {{c1::extensor plantar reflex}}, or {{c1::Babinski reflex}}
Khan Academy Link

Give the hormones that are produced by the anterior pituitary gland:

{{c1::}}
Khan Academy Link

The posterior pituitary stores the following two hormones which are secreted by the hypothalamus:

{{c1::Oxytocin}}
{{c1::Antidiuretic hormone (ADH)}}
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::adrenal glands}} are endocrine glands located above the kidneys and they produce a variety of hormones
Khan Academy Link

The process of fertilization involves the following 4 steps:

1. {{c1::Sperm binding}}
2. {{c1::Acrosome reaction}}
3. {{c1::Cortical reaction}}
4. {{c1::Genetic transfer}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Embryogenesis}} is the process by which the embryo forms and develops
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Gastrulation}} is a phase early in the embryonic development of most animals, during which the single-layered blastula is reorganized into a multilayered structure known as the gastrula
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Neurulation}} results in the formation of the neural tube, which gives rise to both the spinal cord and the brain
YouTube Link
Implantation begins with {{c1::apposition}} of the blastocyst at the uterine epithelium, generally about 2-4 days after the morula enters the uterine cavity

During apposition process, the blastocyst differentiates into an inner cell mass (embryo) and trophectoderm (placenta)


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Gestation}} is the period of time between conception and birth
Khan Academy Link

A pregnancy is divided into the following trimesters:

First trimester is from week {{c1::1}} to the end of week {{c1::12}}

Second trimester is from week {{c1::13}} to the end of week {{c1::26}}

Third trimester is from week {{c1::27}} to {{c1::the end of the pregnancy}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Fine motor::... motor}} skill is the coordination of small muscles in movements; usually involving the synchronisation of hands and fingers with the eyes
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Gross motor::... motor}} skills are large movements a baby makes with his or her arms, legs, feet, or entire body

Crawling, running, and jumping are gross motor skills


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Adolescence}} begins with puberty and is a two year long period of sexual maturation
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Synaptic pruning}} refers to the process by which extra neurons and synaptic connections are eliminated in order to increase the efficiency of neuronal transmissions

Synaptic pruning is thought to help the brain transition from childhood to adulthood


Khan Academy Link
Gene–environment interaction is when {{c1::two different genotypes}} respond to environmental variation in different ways
Khan Academy Link
A study that looks at the interaction between genetic predisposition and environmental events is looking at {{c1::gene-environment interaction}}, not epigenetics
Khan Academy Link

The {{c1::Rutherford Model::... Model}} states that an atom is mostly empty space, with electrons orbiting a fixed, positively charged nucleus

According to the {{c1::Bohr Model::... Model}}, electrons orbit the nucleus in <u>orbits</u> that have a set size and energy

{{c1::Hund’s Rule}} states that all orbitals must first have one electron before any orbital can obtain a second electron

The {{c1::Pauli Exclusion Principle::... Principle}} states that no two electrons can share the<u> same four</u> <u>identical</u> <u>quantum numbers</u>

That means, for paired electrons, one must be +1/2 spin and the other -1/2 spin

<u>Paramagnetic</u> materials are {{c1::pulled<font color="#0d73ff"> </font>into}} an external magnetic field

Quantum number {{c1::n}} is the principal quantum number and gives the electron {{c1::energy level or shell number}}

Except for d- and f-orbitals, the shell # matches the row of the periodic table



Khan Academy Link
Quantum number {{c1::l}} is the azimuthal quantum number and gives the {{c1::3D shape (subshell)}} of an orbital

0, 1, 2, …, n-1

0 = s orbital
1 = p orbital
2 = d orbital
3 = f orbital
4 = g orbital



Khan Academy Link
Quantum number {{c1::ml}} is the magnetic quantum number and gives the orbital {{c1::sub-type}}

Khan Academy Link
Quantum number {{c1::m<sub>s</sub>}} is the <u>spin</u> quantum number and gives the {{c1::electronic spin}} of the electron

+1/2 or -1/2



Khan Academy Link
The maximum number of electrons in a single energy level in terms of principal quantum number = {{c1::2n2}}

Example: What is the maximum number of electrons that can be in the second energy level?

2n2 = 2(22) = 8 electrons


YouTube Link
The maximum number of electrons in a single subshell in terms of the azimuthal quantum number = {{c1::4l + 2}}

The number of orbitals in a subshell = 2l + 1

With a maximum of 2 electrons per orbital, the maximum number of electrons per subshell = 2(2l + 1) = 4l + 2

Example: For the d subshell, we know the mathematical value for d is l = 2

4l + 2 = 4(2) + 2 = 10 electrons at maximum in the d subshell

Weak acids and bases do not completely {{c1::dissociate}}

{{c1::Kb}} is the equilibrium constant corresponding to the dissociation of a base, BOH, into a hydroxide ion and its conjugate acid

pK<sub>a</sub> = {{c1::-log(K<sub>a</sub>)}}
Khan Academy Link
pKb = {{c1::-log(Kb)}}

pK<sub>a</sub> + pK<sub>b</sub> = {{c1::pK<sub>w</sub>}} = {{c1::14::#}}
Khan Academy Link
Strong acids and bases have {{c1::weak::strong or weak}} conjugates
Khan Academy Link
Weak acids and bases have {{c1::weak::strong or weak}} conjugates
Khan Academy Link
A neutralization reaction is when an acid and a base react to form {{c1::water}} and {{c1::a salt}}

H+ ions and OH- ions combine to generate water


Khan Academy Link
An acidic buffer is a mixture of a {{c1::weak acid}} and {{c1::its conjugate salt}}
Khan Academy Link
A basic buffer is a mixture of a {{c1::weak base}} and {{c1::its conjugate salt}}

Buffering capacity is a measure of the ability of a buffer to {{c1::resist changes in pH}}

Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::equivalence point}} is the point at which equivalent amounts of acid and base have reacted
Khan Academy Link
In a titration, the {{c1::titrant}} (the known solution) is added from a burette to a certain quantity of the {{c1::analyte}} (the unknown solution) until the reaction is complete

The graph above shows the titration curve of a {{c1::weak acid}} with a {{c1::strong base}}
Khan Academy Link
The graph above shows the titration curve of a {{c1::weak acid}} with a {{c1::weak base}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Indicators}} are weak acids or bases that display different colors in the protonated and deprotonated forms
Khan Academy Link
When choosing a titration indicator, you want to select an indicator that changes color in a range close to your {{c1::equivalence point::point on titration curve}}
Khan Academy Link

In an acid:

{{c1::red::red or blue}} litmus paper has no change of color

{{c1::blue::red or blue}} litmus paper changes its color to {{c1::red::red or blue}}

{{c1::blue::red or blue}} litmus paper has no change of color

Universal litmus paper turns {{c1::red, orange or yellow::colors}} in acids, {{c1::green::color}} in neutral solutions and {{c1::blue or purple::colors}} in alkalis

Methyl orange is red at a pH less than {{c1::3.1}} and is yellow at a pH greater than {{c1::4.4}}

The endpoint of a titration is when {{c1::the indicator reaches full color}}

Titrations of a/an {{c1::polyvalent acid or base}} show multiple buffering regions and equivalence points

At the half-equivalence point (midpoint) of a titration, pH = {{c1::pKa}}

Any free element or diatomic species has an oxidation number of {{c1::0::#}}

A monatomic ion has an oxidation charge that equals {{c1::the charge of the ion}}

When in a compound, metals have the following oxidation states:

Group 1A metals = {{c1::+1::#}}

Group 2A metals = {{c1::+2::#}}

When in a compound, group 7A metals have an oxidation state of {{c1::-1::#}} unless combined with an element of greater electronegativity

The oxidation state of oxygen in a compound is {{c1::-2::#}}, except for peroxides like H2O2, and Na2O2, in which the oxidation state for O is {{c1::-1::#}}

The sum of the oxidation numbers in a neutral compound is {{c1::zero::#}}

The sum of the oxidation numbers in a polyatomic ion is equal to {{c1::the charge of the ion}}

The {{c1::complete ionic equation::... equation}} shows all of the ions present in a reaction including spectator ions

The {{c1::net ionic equation::... equation}} is a chemical equation for a reaction which lists only those species participating in the reaction

Does not include spectator ions

{{c1::Disproportionation}}, also known as {{c1::dismutation}}, is a REDOX reaction where a molecule is transformed into two or more dissimilar products

A/an {{c1::REDOX titration::... titration}} is similar in methodology to acid-base titrations, however, these titrations follow transfer of charge

In an electrochemical cell, a cathode attracts {{c1::cations::anions or cations}} and is always the site of {{c1::reduction::oxidation or reduction}}

In an electrochemical cell, electrons flow from the {{c1::anode::anode or cathode}} to the {{c1::cathode::anode or cathode}}

In an electrochemical cell, current flows from the {{c1::cathode::anode or cathode}} to the {{c1::anode::anode or cathode}}

{{c1::Reduction potential}} is a measure of the tendency of a chemical species gain electrons and be reduced

A more positive Ered indicates a greater tendency to be reduced

The {{c1::standard reduction potential}} is the tendency for a chemical species to be reduced, and is measured in volts at standard conditions

The {{c1::electromotive force (EMF)}} is the maximum potential difference between two electrodes of a galvanic or voltaic cell

Also known as the cell potential

{{c1::Alkanes}} are hydrocarbons in which all carbon–carbon bonds are single bonds
Khan Academy Link
Alkanes are named according to the number of {{c1::carbons}} present followed by the suffix {{c1::–ane}}
Khan Academy Link
Alkenes have a {{c1::double}} bond and use the suffix {{c1::-ene}}
Khan Academy Link
<u>Alkynes</u> have a {{c1::triple}} bond and use the suffix {{c1::–yne}}
Khan Academy Link
Alcohols have a/an {{c1::–OH}} group and use the suffix {{c1::–ol}} or prefix {{c1::hydroxy-}}

Alcohols have higher priority than double or triple bonds


Khan Academy Link
<u>Diols</u> contain two {{c1::hydroxyl}} groups
Khan Academy Link
This compound is named {{c1::methane}}
Khan Academy Link
This compound is named {{c1::propane}}
Khan Academy Link
This compound is named {{c1::butane}}
Khan Academy Link
This compound is named {{c1::pentane}}
Khan Academy Link
This compound is named {{c1::hexane}}
Khan Academy Link
This functional group is called a/an {{c1::carbonyl group}}
Khan Academy Link
Aldehydes have a carbonyl group on the {{c1::terminal::terminal or non-terminal}} carbon
Khan Academy Link
<u>Ketones</u> have carbonyl group on a {{c1::non-terminal::terminal or non-terminal}} carbon
Khan Academy Link
Alcohols are classified as 1º, 2º, and 3º alcohols according to the number of carbons attached to the {{c1::carbon bearing the hydroxyl group}}

In other words, whether the hydroxyl is bound to a primary, secondary, or tertiary carbon


Khan Academy Link
Amines are classified as 1º, 2º, and 3º amines according to the number of carbons attached to the {{c1::nitrogen atom}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Carboxylic acid}} is the highest priority functional group

This is because it contains 3 bonds to oxygen


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Isomers}} have the same chemical formula but have a different stereochemical arrangement of their atoms
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Constitutional (structural) isomers::... isomers}} have identical chemical formulas but differ structurally

The share only a molecular formula. Have different physical and chemical properties



Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Stereoisomers}} are connected in the same order but differ in 3D orientation
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::chiral center}} is when four different groups are attached to a central carbon
Khan Academy Link
For n number of chiral carbons, there are {{c1::2n}} possible stereoisomers
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Conformational isomers::... isomers}} differ by rotation around a single σ bond
Khan Academy Link
This Newman projection shows {{c1::anti}} conformation

The carbon attachments are on opposite ends, 180 degrees apart


Khan Academy Link
This Newman projection shows {{c1::gauche}} conformation

The carbon attachments are 60 degrees apart


Khan Academy Link
This Newman projection is {{c1::eclipsed}} conformation

Less favorable because it forces more interactions between the front and back attachments, creating more strain


Khan Academy Link
An {{c1::equatorial bond::... bond}} is a bond which is perpendicular to the axis of the ring

The bond lies along the equator of the chair


Khan Academy Link
An {{c1::axial bond::... bond}} is a bond which is <u>parallel</u> to the axis of the ring

"Straight up and down"


Khan Academy Link
The two categories of {{c1::configurational isomers::... isomers}} are enantiomers and diastereomers

Can only change from one form to another by breaking and reforming bonds


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Enantiomers}} are stereoisomers that are <u>non-superimposable</u> and <u>are mirror images</u> of each other

Same chemical and physical properties, except for rotation of plane polarized light



Khan Academy Link
Optical activity is the ability of a molecule to {{c1::rotate}} plane-polarized light
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::racemic}} mixture is a 50:50 mixture of two enantiomers

Not optically active because the light rotations cancel out


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Meso compounds}} have an internal plane of symmetry

Will be optically inactive because the two sides of the molecule cancel each other out




Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Diastereomers}} are stereoisomers that are non-superimposable and are not mirror images of each other
Khan Academy Link

Cis functional groups are on {{c1::the same}} side

Trans functional groups are on {{c1::opposing}} sides
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Relative configuration::.. configuration}} gives the stereochemistry of a compound relative to the D- and L- forms of glyceraldehyde

In a Fischer projection, look at the highest numbered chiral carbon

If -OH is on the right then it is a D-sugar. If -OH is on left then it is an L-sugar


Chem Libre Link
The stereochemistry of the α-carbon in all eukaryotic amino acids (except glycine) is {{c1::L}}
YouTube Link
{{c1::Absolute configuration::... configuration}} gives the stereochemistry of a compound without having to compare to other compounds
Khan Academy Link
Cahn-Ingold-Prelog priority rules are rules for {{c1::naming stereoisomers}}

Priority is given by looking at atoms connected to the chiral carbon or double-bonded carbons. Whichever has the highest atomic # gets highest priority



Khan Academy Link

In the E-Z naming system for alkenes:

(Z) has the highest priority on {{c1::the same}} side(s)

(E) has the highest priority on {{c1::opposite}} side(s)
Khan Academy Link

In Fischer projections:

Vertical lines go to {{c1::back}} of the page

Horizontal lines {{c1::come out of the}} page

Vertical lines are like dashes

Horizontal lines are like wedges


Khan Academy Link
Quantum number n is the {{c1::principal}} quantum number and gives the electron {{c1::energy level or shell number}}

1, 2, 3, ...

Except for d- and f-orbitals, the shell # matches the row of the periodic table



Khan Academy Link
Quantum number l is the {{c1::azimuthal}} quantum number and gives the {{c1::3D shape (subshell)}} of an orbital

0, 1, 2, …, n-1

0 = s orbital
1 = p orbital
2 = d orbital
3 = f orbital
4 = g orbital



Khan Academy Link
Quantum number ml is the {{c1::magnetic}} quantum number and gives the orbital {{c1::sub-type}}

Integers -l to +l

The orientation of the electron's orbital with respect to the three axes in space, x, y, and z.



Khan Academy Link
Quantum number ms is the {{c1::spin}} quantum number and gives the {{c1::electronic spin}} of the electron

+1/2 or -1/2



Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Molecular}} orbitals are obtained by combining the {{c1::atomic}} orbitals from the individual atoms that make up the molecule

Molecular orbital theory is able to explain why some bonds between atoms are observed to be in between a single and a double bond. Valence-bond theory, the more traditional theory, cannot explain these "hybridized" bonds


YouTube Link
<u>Bonding orbitals</u> are created by overlap of atomic orbitals of the {{c1::same::same or opposite}} sign
YouTube Link
Antibonding orbitals are created by overlap of atomic orbitals of the {{c1::opposite::same or opposite}} signs
YouTube Link

Give the number of sigma and pi bonds for each bond order

{{c1::}}
YouTube Link
Multiple bonds are {{c1::less::more or less}} flexible than single bonds

This is because rotation is not permitted in the presence of a π bond


Khan Academy Link
Multiple bonds are {{c1::shorter::shorter or longer}} than single bonds
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Orbital hybridization}} is the idea that atomic orbitals fuse to form newly hybridized orbitals

Includes sp3, sp2, and sp


Khan Academy Link
sp3 hybridization is {{c1::25%::%}} s character and {{c1::75%::%}} p character
Khan Academy Link
sp2 hybridization is {{c1::33%::%}} s character and {{c1::67%::%}} p character
Khan Academy Link
<u>sp</u><sup> </sup>hybridization is {{c1::50%::%}} s character and {{c1::50%::%}} p character
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Conjugation}} occurs when single and multiple bonds alternate

This creates a system of unhybridized p orbitals down the backbone of the molecule through which p electrons can delocalize




YouTube Link
{{c1::Resonance}} is the delocalization of electrons in molecules that have conjugated bonds
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Lewis}} acids are electron acceptors

Contain vacant orbitals or positive polarized atoms


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Lewis}} bases are <u>electron </u>donors

Contain a lone pair of electrons and are often anions


Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::Brønsted-Lowry}} acid is a <u>proton</u> donor
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::Brønsted-Lowry}} base is a <u>proton</u> acceptor
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Amphoteric}} molecules can act as either acids or bases
YouTube Link
Ka is the {{c1::acid dissociation}} constant

An indicator of acid strength

It is the equilibrium constant corresponding to the dissociation of an acid, HA, into a proton and its conjugate base


Khan Academy Link
Low pKa = {{c1::strong::weak or strong}} acid
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::REDOX}} reaction is a reaction with the transfer of electrons from the substance being oxidized to the substance being reduced
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Oxidation number}} is the charge an atom would have if all its bonds were completely ionic
Khan Academy Link
In REDOX reactions, the {{c1::oxidized::oxidized or reduced}} molecule <u>loses</u> electrons and the oxidation number <u>increases</u>
Khan Academy Link
An oxidizing agent {{c1::accepts::accepts or donates}} electrons and is {{c1::reduced::oxidized or reduced}} in the process
Khan Academy Link
In REDOX reactions, the {{c1::reduced::oxidized or reduced}} molecule gains electrons and the oxidation number decreases
Khan Academy Link
A <u>reducing agent</u> {{c1::donates::accepts or donates}} electrons and is {{c1::oxidized::oxidized or reduced}} in the process
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Chemoselectivity}} is the ability of a reagent or inter­mediate to react with one group or atom in a mole­cule in preference to another group or atom present in the same molecule
YouTube Link
A/an {{c1::nucleophile}} contains lone pairs of electrons or pi bonds and is “Nucleus-loving”

Often carries a negative charge


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Nucleophilicity}} is a term used to describe the strength of a  nucleophile

Nucleophilicity is affected by: 

Charge
Electronegativity
Steric hindrance
Solvent


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Electrophiles}} are <u>electron loving</u>

Contain a positive charge or are positively polarized


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Leaving groups}} are molecular fragments that <u>retain the electrons</u> after heterolysis

The best LG can stabilize additional charge through resonance or induction

Weak bases make good leaving groups


Khan Academy Link
Cl<sup>-</sup> and Br<sup>-</sup> are {{c1::good::good or bad}} leaving groups
Khan Academy Link
-OH is a {{c1::bad::good or bad}} leaving group
Khan Academy Link
The "SN" in SN1 and SN2 reactions refers to {{c1::nucleophilic substitution}}
Khan Academy Link
The number 1 in an SN1 reaction refers to the fact that the reaction is {{c1::unimolecular}}

SN1 Rate = k[substrate]1 = a first-order reaction


YouTube Link
An SN1 reaction has {{c1::two::#}} step(s)

Step 1:  The LG leaves, forming a carbocation

Step 2: The nucleophile attacks the planar carbocation from either side, leading to a racemic mixture of products



Khan Academy Link
An S<sub>N</sub>2 reaction has {{c1::one::#}} step(s)

The nucleophile attacks at the same time as the LG leaves

The nucleophile must perform a backside attack, which leads to inversion of stereochemistry



Khan Academy Link
{{c1::SN1::SN1 or SN2}} products are a racemic mixture

In the 2nd step, the nucleophile attacks the planar carbocation from either side, leading to a racemic mixture of products


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::S<sub>N</sub>2::S<sub>N</sub>1 or S<sub>N</sub>2}} reactions lead to <u>inversion</u> of stereochemistry

The nucleophile must perform a backside attack, which leads to
inversion of stereochemistry


Khan Academy Link
The rate law for an SN1 reaction is {{c1::SN1 Rate = k[substrate]1}}

A first-order reaction


YouTube Link
The rate law for an SN2 reaction is {{c1::SN2 Rate = k[substrate]1[nucleophile]1}}

A second-order reaction


YouTube Link
A primary substrate will go {{c1::SN2::SN1 or SN2}}

1 step

If you were to do an SN1 reaction on a primary substrate, you'd get a primary carbocation, which is very unstable


YouTube Link
A tertiary substrate with a protic (or aprotic) solvent will go {{c1::SN1::SN1 or SN2}}

2 steps

There is too much steric hinderance for the nucleophile to attack the carbon while the leaving group is still there. The LG must leave first

The products will be a mixture of SN1 and E1


YouTube Link
This reaction will go {{c1::SN1::SN1 or SN2}}

The substrate is secondary and CH3OH is a protic solvent



YouTube Link
This reaction will go {{c1::SN2::SN1 or SN2}}

The substrate is secondary and acetone is an aprotic solvent 



YouTube Link
SN2 reactions prefer {{c1::methyl and primary}} substrates

It is easy for the nucleophile to attack the carbon because the carbon is accessible (less steric hindrance)

The reaction can proceed in 1 step


YouTube Link
A methyl substrate cannot undergo an elimination reaction because elimination reactions create {{c1::double bonds between two carbons, C=C}}

There is only one carbon in a methyl so no double bond can be created


YouTube Link
Strong bases favor {{c1::E2}} reactions
YouTube Link
A secondary substrate with a protic solvent will go {{c1::SN1::SN1 or SN2}}
YouTube Link
A secondary substrate with an aprotic solvent will go {{c1::SN2::SN1 or SN2}}
YouTube Link
Polar {{c1::protic::protic or aprotic}} solvents are capable of <u>hydrogen bonding</u>

Polar Protic: Acetic Acid, H2O, ROH, NH3


Khan Academy Link
Polar {{c1::aprotic::protic or aprotic}} solvents do not participate in hydrogen bonding

Polar Aprotic: DMF, DMSO, Acetone, Ethyl Acetate


Khan Academy Link
Acetic acid is polar {{c1::protic::protic or aprotic}}

Polar protic because it participates in hydrogen bonding


Khan Academy Link
DMSO is polar {{c1::aprotic::protic or aprotic}}

Dimethyl sulfoxide is polar aprotic because it does not participate in hydrogen bonding


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Alcohols}} use suffix –ol or prefix hydroxy-

Contains an –OH group

Alcohols have higher priority than double or triple bonds


Khan Academy Link
1º, 2º, and 3º alcohols are named according to the number of carbons attached to {{c1::the carbon bearing the hydroxyl group::which carbon}}

In other words, whether the hydroxyl is bound to a primary, secondary, or tertiary carbon


Khan Academy Link
This is a {{c1::primary::primary, secondary, or tertiary}} alcohol
Khan Academy Link
This is a {{c1::secondary::primary, secondary, or tertiary}} alcohol
Khan Academy Link
This is a {{c1::tertiary::primary, secondary, or tertiary}} alcohol
Khan Academy Link
This compound is known as a/an {{c1::phenol}}

Benzene ring with –OH group attached

Named for the relative position of the –OH groups


Khan Academy Link
The substituents on this benzene ring are in {{c1::ortho}} position
YouTube Link
The substituents on this benzene ring are in {{c1::meta}} position
YouTube Link
The substituents on this benzene ring are in {{c1::para}} position
YouTube Link
{{c1::Quinones}} are conjugated cyclic diketones but are not aromatic

Synthesized through oxidation of phenols

Examples:

Vitamin K1 (phylloquinone)
Vitamin K2 (the menaquinones)


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Hydroxyquinones}} are produced by oxidation of quinones

Adds a variable number of hydroxyl groups


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Ubiquinone}} is a biologically active quinone that acts as an electron acceptor in complexes I, II, and III of the electron transport chain

Also called coenzyme Q

It is reduced to ubiquinol


Khan Academy Link

When an alcohol is oxidized it becomes one of the following compounds:

{{c1::aldehyde}}
{{c1::ketone}}
{{c1::carboxylic acid}}

Oxidation of an alcohol removes the H and adds a second bond to the O to make a carbonyl


Khan Academy Link
Treatment of an alcohol with pyridinium chlorochromate (PCC) leads to the formation of a/an {{c1::aldehyde}}

Any stronger oxidizing agent will oxidize the alcohol all the way to carboxylic acid


YouTube Link
<u>-OH</u> is a {{c1::bad::good or bad}} leaving group
Khan Academy Link
Alcohols can be converted to {{c1::mesylates}} or {{c1::tosylates}} to make them better leaving groups for nucleophilic substitution reactions
Khan Academy Link
Aldehydes and ketones be protected by converting them into {{c1::acetals}} or {{c1::ketals}}
Khan Academy Link
This is a/an {{c1::acetal}}

A primary carbon with two –OR groups and a hydrogen atom



Khan Academy Link
This is a/an {{c1::ketal}}

A secondary carbon with two –OR groups



Khan Academy Link
Amino acids are simple organic compounds containing both a/an {{c1::carboxyl (—COOH)}} group and a/an {{c1::amino (—NH2)}} group
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::amine functional group::... functional group}} is a basic nitrogen atom with a lone pair of electrons
Khan Academy Link
An amide functional group has a/an {{c1::carbonyl}} group linked to a/an {{c1::nitrogen}} atom
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Aliphatic}} compounds are hydrocarbon compounds containing carbon and hydrogen joined together in straight chains, branched chains, or non-aromatic rings

Aliphatic amino acids are Gly, Ala, Val, Leu, Ile, Pro

Met can also be considered aliphatic



YouTube Link
Peptide Bonds are formed when the {{c1::N-terminus}} of an amino acid nucleophilically attacks the {{c1::C-terminus}} of another amino acid

Condensation reaction

Can be cleaved hydrolytically using a strong acid or base


Khan Academy Link
In a peptide bond, rotation of the C-N bond is restricted due to {{c1::resonance}}

Resonance causes the C-N bond to take on a partial double bond character


Khan Academy Link
Polypeptides are made up of multiple {{c1::amino acids}} linked by {{c1::peptide bonds}}

Proteins are large, folded, functional polypeptides


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Strecker synthesis::... synthesis}} and {{c1::Gabriel synthesis::... synthesis}} are two common methods of synthesizing amino acids in the lab
Khan Academy Link
Strecker synthesis generates an amino acid from a/an {{c1::aldehyde}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Gabriel synthesis}} generates an amino acid from potassium phthalimide, diethyl bromomalonate, and an alkyl halide
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Phosphoric acid}} is sometimes referred to as a phosphate group or inorganic phosphate

Denoted as Pi


YouTube Link
Phosphoric acid is an excellent buffer because it contains three hydrogens, each with {{c1::a unique pKa}}

The wide variety in pKa values allows phosphoric acid to act as a buffer over a large range of pH values


YouTube Link
{{c1::Phosphodiester bonds::... bonds}} make up the backbone of DNA
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Organic phosphates}} are carbon containing compounds that also have phosphate groups

The most notable examples are nucleotide triphosphates (ATP or GTP) and DNA

ATP Structure:


Khan Academy Link
An aldehyde is a terminal functional group containing a/an {{c1::carbonyl}} bonded to at least one {{c1::hydrogen}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Aldehydes}} have the suffix -al

Aldehydes take their name from their parent alkane chains

The -e is removed from the end and is replaced with -al


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Ketones}} use the suffix -one and the prefixes oxo- or keto-

Ketones take their name from their parent alkane chains

The ending -e is removed and replaced with -one


Khan Academy Link
The aldehyde functional group is given the number {{c1::1}} numbering location
Khan Academy Link
A ketone is an <u>internal functional group</u> containing a/an {{c1::carbonyl}} bonded to two {{c1::alkyl chains}}
Khan Academy Link
A {{c1::carbonyl}} is a carbon-oxygen double bond
Khan Academy Link
Aldehydes and ketones are synthesized from alcohols through {{c1::oxidation}}
Khan Academy Link
A weak oxidizing agent like {{c1::pyridinium chlorochromate (PCC)}} must be used for synthesizing aldehydes from alcohols, or else the reaction will continue oxidizing and form a carboxylic acid
Khan Academy Link
KMnO<sub>4 </sub>and H<sub>2</sub>Cr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> are {{c1::strong::weak or strong}} oxidizing agents

They will oxidize an alcohol all the way into a ketone or carboxylic acid


Khan Academy Link
NaBH<sub>4</sub> is a {{c1::weak::weak or strong}} reducing agent

It will reduce an aldehyde or a ketone into an alcohol, but will not reduce a carboxylic acid or an ester


Khan Academy Link
A strong reducing agent like {{c1::LiAlH4 (LAH)}} is needed to reduce a carboxylic acid or an ester into an alcohol
Khan Academy Link
Nucleophilic addition reactions involve the attack of a nucleophile on the slightly positive {{c1::carbon center}} of a carbonyl group
Khan Academy Link
In a hydration reaction, water adds to a carbonyl and forms a/an {{c1::geminal diol}}
Khan Academy Link
When one equivalent of alcohol reacts with an aldehyde, a/an {{c1::hemiacetal}} is formed
Khan Academy Link
When one equivalent of alcohol reacts with a ketone, a/an {{c1::hemiketal}} is formed
Khan Academy Link
When two equivalents of alcohol react with an aldehyde, a/an {{c1::acetal}} is formed
Khan Academy Link
When two equivalents of alcohol react with a ketone, a/an {{c1::ketal}} is formed
Khan Academy Link
Nitrogen and nitrogen derivatives react with carbonyls to form {{c1::imines}}
Khan Academy Link
Imines can tautomerize to form {{c1::enamines}}

Tautomerization is a reaction which involves simple proton transfer


Khan Academy Link
Hydrogen cyanide reacts with carbonyls to form {{c1::cyanohydrins}}
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::}}
Khan Academy Link

Identify the α-hydrogens

{{c1::}}
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::enolate anion}} is formed when an α-hydrogen in the molecule of an aldehyde or a ketone is removed
Khan Academy Link
Aldehydes are usually {{c1::more::more or less}} reactive toward nucleophilic substitutions than ketones because of both steric and electronic effects
Khan Academy Link
This is the {{c1::keto::keto or enol}} form of acetone

Keto form has a regular ketone or an aldehyde

Enol form contains an alcohol


Khan Academy Link
The term "<u>enol</u>" comes from the fact that it is a/an {{c1::alkene}} that is also a/an {{c1::alcohol}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Keto-enol tautomerization}} refers to a chemical equilibrium between a keto form and an enol

The keto and enol forms are said to be tautomers of each other

They can be interconverted by moving a hydrogen and a double bond


Khan Academy Link
Keto form is much {{c1::more::more or less}} common than enol form

Can be attributed to the fact that a C=O double bond is significantly more stable (higher bond energy) than a C=C double bond


Khan Academy Link
In a Michael addition, a/an {{c1::enolate}} attacks a/an {{c1::α,β-unsaturated carbonyl}}, creating a bond
YouTube Link
Removal of a proton from the less substituted (and less hindered) α-carbon gives the {{c1::kinetic::kinetic or thermodynamic}} enolate

The kinetic enolate has the less substituted C=C double bond


Khan Academy Link
Removal of a proton from the more substituted (and more hindered) α-carbon gives the {{c1::thermodynamic::kinetic or thermodynamic}} enolate

The thermodynamic enolate has the more substituted C=C double bond


Khan Academy Link
An aldol is a/an {{c1::aldehyde}} plus a/an {{c1::alcohol}}
Khan Academy Link
Aldol addition is a powerful way to create a {{c1::carbon-carbon}} bond
Khan Academy Link
An aldol condensation starts with a/an {{c1::aldol addition}} to create a/an {{c1::aldol}}

Then it undergoes a dehydration to give a conjugated enone (α,β-unsaturated carbonyl)

Very common in the production of pharmaceuticals and perfumes


Khan Academy Link
An aldol nucleophile is the {{c1::enolate}} formed from the deprotonation of the α-carbon
Khan Academy Link
The aldol electrophile is a/an {{c1::aldehyde}} or {{c1::ketone}}
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::retro-aldol reaction::... reaction}} is the reverse of an aldol reaction

The bond between the α- and β-carbon is cleaved

Catalyzed by heat


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Carboxylic acid}} functional groups contain a carbonyl and a hydroxyl group connected to the same carbon

They are always terminal groups


Khan Academy Link
Carboxylic acids use the suffix {{c1::–oic acid}}

Salts are named with the suffix –oate


Khan Academy Link
Carboxylic acids have a high <u>boiling point</u> due to {{c1::hydrogen bonding}}

They often exist as dimers in solution due to the hydrogen bonding


Khan Academy Link
The acidity of a carboxylic acid can be enhanced by substituents that are electron-{{c1::withdrawing::withdrawing or donating}}
Khan Academy Link
The acidity of a carboxylic acid can be decreased by substituents that are electron-{{c1::donating::withdrawing or donating}}
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::}}
Khan Academy Link

Identify the most acidic proton

{{c1::}}

This is a β-dicarboxylic acid

Khan Academy Link
Carboxylic acids can be made by the {{c1::oxidation}} of 1° alcohols or aldehydes
Khan Academy Link

KMnO4
Na2Cr2O7
K2Cr2O7
CrO3

The above list shows {{c1::oxidizing::oxidizing or reducing}} agents that can form carboxylic acids

Note: PCC is weak and stops oxidizing at the aldehyde


Khan Academy Link

Identify the functional group in red

{{c1::}}

Acyl Groups are derived by the removal of one or more hydroxyl groups from an oxoacid (acid that contains oxygen)


Khan Academy Link
In nucleophilic acyl substitution a {{c1::nucleophile}} displaces the {{c1::leaving group}}

The nucleophile attacks the electrophilic carbonyl carbon, opening the carbonyl and forming a tetrahedral intermediate

The carbonyl reforms, kicking off the leaving group


Khan Academy Link
The nitrogen containing functional group shown above is called a/an {{c1::amide}}

Amides are synthesized from a carboxylic acid by replacing the –OH group with an amino group that may or may not be substituted


Khan Academy Link
Amides are given the suffix {{c1::–amide}}
Khan Academy Link
Amides are derivatives of carboxylic acids in which the {{c1::hydroxyl}} group has been replaced by a/an {{c1::amine or ammonia}}
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::ester}} is a carboxylic acid derivative where –OH is replaced with -OR
Khan Academy Link
Esters are given the suffix {{c1::–oate}}
Khan Academy Link
Carboxylic acid can act as a nucleophile and attack a second carboxylic acid to form a/an {{c1::anhydride}}
Khan Academy Link
Both linear and cyclic anhydrides are given the suffix {{c1::anhydride}}
Khan Academy Link
A carboxylic acid can be reduced to a 1° alcohol with a strong reducing agent like {{c1::LiAlH4}}

NaBH4 is not strong enough to reduce a carboxylic acid


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Decarboxylation}} is a chemical reaction that removes a carboxyl group and releases carbon dioxide (CO2)

The reaction proceeds spontaneously when heated


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Saponification}} is an ester hydrolysis of triacylglycerols using a strong base like sodium or KOH

They organize in water to form micelles



Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::micelle}} dissolves nonpolar organic molecules in its interior, and can be solvated with water due to its exterior shell of hydrophilic groups
YouTube Link
The reagents used in acid halide synthesis are {{c1::SOCl2}} and {{c1::PBr3}}
Khan Academy Link
This is an example of {{c1::Fischer Esterification}}

Treatment of a carboxylic acid with an alcohol in the presence of an acid catalyst leads to the formation of esters, along with the elimination H2O

Khan Academy Link

Acid chloride
Amides
Anhydrides
Carboxylate
Esters

Place the above molecules in order from most reactive to least reactive in nucleophilic substitution reactions

{{c1::Acid chloride > Anhydrides > Esters > Amides > Carboxylate}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Steric hindrance}} describes when a reaction cannot proceed (or significantly slows) because substituents crowd the reactive site
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Induction}} refers to uneven distribution of charge across a σ bond because of differences in electronegativity

The more electronegative groups a carbonyl-containing compound has, the greater its reactivity



Khan Academy Link
Increased ring strain in a molecule can make it {{c1::more::more or less}} reactive
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Transesterification}} is the process of exchanging the R″ group of an ester with the R′ group of an alcohol

"Transformation of an ester"

Alcohol is the attacking nucleophile


Khan Academy Link
When a phosphodiester bond is formed, a/an {{c1::pyrophosphate (PPi)}} is released

The pyrophosphate can then be hydrolyzed into two inorganic phosphates (Pi)


Khan Academy Link
This is the {{c1::enol::keto or enol}} form of acetone

Enol form contains an alcohol

Keto form has a regular ketone or an aldehyde


Khan Academy Link
High Ka = {{c1::strong::strong or weak}} acid
Khan Academy Link
Multiple bonds are {{c1::stronger::weaker or stronger}} than single bonds
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::pKa}} is the pH at which half of the species is deprotonated

[HA] = [A-]


Khan Academy Link
The number 2 in an SN2 reaction refers to the fact that the reaction is {{c1::bimolecular}}

SN2 Rate = k[substrate]1[nucleophile]1 = a second-order reaction


YouTube Link
Cyclic amides are called {{c1::lactams}}
Khan Academy Link
Cyclic esters are called {{c1::lactones}}
Khan Academy Link

Geminal diols have their two hydroxyl groups attached to {{c1::the same::the same or adjacent}} carbon(s)

Vicinal diols have theirs attached to {{c1::adjacent::the same or adjacent}} carbon(s)
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Infrared spectroscopy::... spectroscopy}} measures absorption of infrared light, which causes molecular vibration such as stretching, bending, twisting, and folding

Based on this it is possible to determine the functional groups that make up the molecule

Plotted as % transmittance vs. wavenumber (\(\frac{1}{λ}\))



YouTube Link
The IR spectroscopy frequency for N-H bonds is {{c1::3300}} cm-1
YouTube Link
The IR spectroscopy frequency range for O-H bonds is {{c1::3000}} - {{c1::3300}} cm-1
YouTube Link
The IR spectroscopy frequency range for CO and CN triple bonds is {{c1::1900}} - {{c1::2200}} cm-1
YouTube Link
The IR spectroscopy frequency for C=O bonds is {{c1::1750}} cm-1
YouTube Link
The IR spectroscopy frequency range for C=C bonds is {{c1::1600}} - {{c1::1680}} cm-1
YouTube Link
The type of bond indicated in this IR spectroscopy chart is {{c1::N-H}}
YouTube Link
The types of bonds indicated in this IR spectroscopy chart are {{c1::C-H}} and {{c1::C=O}}
YouTube Link
The types of bonds indicated in this IR spectroscopy chart are {{c1::O-H}} and {{c1::C-O}}
YouTube Link
{{c1::Ultraviolet spectroscopy::... spectroscopy}} measures the absorption of UV light, which causes <u>movement of electrons between molecular orbitals</u>

UV spectra are plotted as percent transmittance or absorbance vs. wavelength



Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy::... spectroscopy}} measures alignment of nuclear spin with an applied magnetic field

NMR spectroscopy is useful for determining the structure (connectivity) of a compound, including functional groups

Plotted as frequency vs. absorption energy



YouTube Link
NMR spectra are calibrated using {{c1::tetramethylsilane (TMS)}}, which has a chemical shift of 0 ppm
YouTube Link
The {{c1::integration}} is the area under each peak (signal) on the NMR spectrum. It corresponds to the number of protons in that signal
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Deshielding}} in NMR spectroscopy is when a nucleus' chemical shift is increased due to the removal of electron density, magnetic induction, or other effects

Deshielding is the opposite of shielding



Khan Academy Link
In NMR spectroscopy, the {{c1::chemical shift}} is the position on the δ scale (in ppm) where the peak occurs
Khan Academy Link
In NMR spectroscopy, a peak that is <u>deshielded</u> appears {{c1::downfield (left)::downfield or upfield}}
Khan Academy Link
In NMR spectroscopy, a peak that is shielded appears {{c1::upfield (right)::downfield or upfield}}
Khan Academy Link
When hydrogens are on adjacent atoms, they interfere with each other’s magnetic environment, causing {{c1:: spin-spin coupling}} also known as {{c1::splitting}}
Khan Academy Link
In NMR spectroscopy, the multiplicity of a proton or group of protons is given by the n+1 rule, where n = {{c1::the number of protons on the adjacent (adjoining) carbon atom (atoms)}}
Khan Academy Link
The hydrogens of a/an {{c1::alkyl}} group have an NMR range of 0.7 - 1.9 ppm
YouTube Link
A/an {{c1::alkynyl}} hydrogen has an NMR range of 2.5 - 3.0 ppm
YouTube Link
The hydrogens of a/an {{c1::methyl ketone}} have an NMR range of 2.0 - 2.4 ppm
YouTube Link
{{c1::Vinylic}} hydrogens have an NMR range of 4.5 - 6.5 ppm
YouTube Link
The hydrogens of a/an {{c1::aryl}} group have an NMR range of 6.5 - 8.0 ppm
YouTube Link
The hydrogens of a/an {{c1::aldehyde}} group have an NMR range of 9.7 - 10.0 ppm
YouTube Link
The hydrogens of a/an {{c1::carboxylic acid}} group have an NMR range of approximately 11.0 - 12.0 ppm
YouTube Link

A mass spectrometer ionizes atoms and molecules with a high-energy electron beam and then deflects the ions through a magnetic field based on the {{c1::mass-to-charge ratio (\(\frac{m}{z}\))}} of the ion

The mass spectrum of a sample shows relative abundance of each ion on the y-axis and \(\frac{m}{z}\) along the x-axis


YouTube Link
The largest peak in the mass spectrum, corresponding to the most abundant ion, is called the {{c1::base peak}}
YouTube Link
In the mass spectrum, the heaviest ion (the one with the greatest m/z value) is likely to be the {{c1::molecular ion}}
YouTube Link
In a mass spectrum, the {{c1::M+1}} peak is a small peak <u>1 \(\frac{m}{z}\) unit to the right </u>of the main molecular ion peak

The M+1 peak shows the relative abundance of 13C

13C is found in relative abundance of 1.1%

So, if M+1 has an \(\frac{m}{z}\) value of 4.4, that means there are 4 carbons since \(\frac{4.4}{1.1}\) = 4


YouTube Link
In a mass spectrum, the M+2 peak shows the relative abundance of either {{c1::81Br}} or {{c1::37Cl}}

Br has a 1:1 ratio relative to the M peak

Cl has a 3:1 ratio relative to the M peak



YouTube Link

In a mass spectrum:

Br has a {{c1::1:1}} ratio relative to the M peak

Cl has a {{c1::3:1}} ratio relative to the M peak
YouTube Link
Based on the size of the M+2 peak, you know this is a mass spectrum of a molecule that contains {{c1::bromine::element}}

Br has a 1:1 ratio relative to the M peak


YouTube Link
Based on the size of the M+2 peak, you know this is a mass spectrum of a molecule that contains {{c1::chlorine::element}}

Cl has a 3:1 ratio relative to the M peak


YouTube Link
A/an {{c1::extraction}} combines two immiscible liquids, one of which easily dissolves the compound of interest
Khan Academy Link
In an extraction, the {{c1::nonpolar::polar or nonpolar}} layer is the organic layer and dissolves nonpolar compounds
Khan Academy Link
In an extraction, the {{c1::polar::polar or nonpolar}} layer is the aqueous (water) layer and dissolves compounds with hydrogen bonding or polarity
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::wash}} is the reverse of an extraction. A small amount of solute that dissolves impurities is run over the compound of interest
YouTube Link
During a filtration, a solid, also known as the {{c1::residue}}, is isolated from a liquid, also known as the {{c1::filtrate}}
YouTube Link
{{c1::Gravity filtration::... filtration}} can be used to collect solid product, although generally {{c1::vacuum filtration::... filtration}} is used for this purpose because it is faster

YouTube Link - Gravity Filtration

YouTube Link - Vacuum Filtration
{{c1::Recrystallization}}, also known as {{c1::fractional crystallization}}, is a procedure for purifying an impure compound in a solvent

An impure compound is dissolved to prepare a highly concentrated solution at a high temperature

The solution is cooled

Decreasing the temperature causes the solubility of the impurities in the solution and the substance being purified to decrease

The impure substance then crystallizes before the impurities- assuming that there was more impure substance than there were impurities




YouTube Link
Chromatography is a laboratory technique for the separation of a mixture based on {{c1::how fast each component travels through a structure}}

The mixture is dissolved in a fluid called the mobile phase, which carries it through a structure holding another material called the stationary phase

The various constituents of the mixture travel at different speeds, causing them to separate


Khan Academy Link
In chromatography, the stationary phase is typically {{c1::polar}} and this causes {{c1::polar}} molecules to elute slower
Khan Academy Link
In chromatography, the mobile phase is typically {{c1::nonpolar}} and this causes {{c1::nonpolar}} molecules to elute faster
Khan Academy Link
In a typical thin-layer chromatography setup, the spot that moves farthest is the {{c1::nonpolar}} substance and the spot that moves the shortest distance is the {{c1::polar}} substance

The stationary phase is typically silica gel, which is polar


Khan Academy Link
In liquid chromatography, {{c1::silica}} is a common stationary phase while {{c1::toluene}} or another nonpolar liquid is used as the mobile phase
Khan Academy Link

{{c1::High-performance liquid chromatography::... chromatography}} relies on pumps to pass a pressurized liquid solvent containing the sample mixture through a column filled with a solid adsorbent material

This gives HPLC higher resolving power


YouTube Link
In gas chromatography, the liquid sample is vaporized before separation. Molecules are separated based on their {{c1::polarity}} and {{c1::boiling point}}

The stationary phase is a thin layer of material applied to the inside of the column

Typically the polarity of the stationary phase matches that of the solute

The mobile phase is an inert gas


Khan Academy Link
Gel-filtration chromatography separates molecules based on their {{c1::size}}

Also known as size-exclusion chromatography

Smaller molecules enter the porous gel beads causing them to elute slower

Larger molecules do not fit in the pores so they elute faster


YouTube Link
In <u>size-exclusion chromatography</u>, large molecules will elute {{c1::first::first or last}}

Larger molecules do not fit in the pores so they elute faster

Smaller molecules enter the porous gel beads causing them to elute later


YouTube Link
Ion exchange chromatography separates proteins by their {{c1::net charge}}

The column is filled with charged beads; either positively or negatively charged

Cation Exchange: negatively charged beads. Negatively charged proteins elute first

Anion Exchange: positvely charged beads. Positively charged proteins elute first


YouTube Link

In <u>anion exchange chromatography</u>, the beads are {{c1::positively::positively or negatively}} charged and this causes {{c1::positively::positively or negatively}} charged proteins to elute first
YouTube Link
In cation exchange chromatography, the beads are {{c1::negatively::positively or negatively}} charged and this causes {{c1::negatively::positively or negatively}} charged proteins to elute first
YouTube Link
Affinity chromatography separates proteins based on {{c1::their affinity for a specific ligand}}

Beads are bound to a specific ligand and proteins with a high affinity for that ligand will bind to the beads

Proteins with a low affinity for the ligand will elute first


YouTube Link
In a typical thin-layer chromatography setup, the stationary phase is made up of {{c1::silica gel::substance}} which is {{c1::polar::polar or nonpolar}}

Polar molecules are slowed by the stationary phase. Nonpolar molecules are repelled by the stationary phase and elute first


Khan Academy Link

The retention factor in thin-layer chromatography is:

Rf = {{c1::\(\frac{distance~the~spot~moved}{distance~the~solvent~front~moved}\)}}
Khan Academy Link
A distillation separates liquids according to differences in their {{c1::boiling points}}

The liquid with the lowest BP vaporizes first and is collected as the distillate


Khan Academy Link
Simple distillation can be used if the boiling points are under 150°C and are at least {{c1::25°C::#°C}} apart
Khan Academy Link

Vacuum distillation should be used if the boiling points are over 150°C to prevent degradation of the product. The vacuum {{c1::
lowers the air pressure}}, which decreases the BP of the liquid
YouTube Link
Fractional distillation is a process by which components in a mixture are separated into different parts (called fractions) according to their different {{c1::boiling points}}
Khan Academy Link

fields: {{c1::Vectors}} are physical quantities that have both magnitude and direction

Examples: displacement, velocity, acceleration, and force



Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Scalars}} are quantities that have only a magnitude
Khan Academy Link
For vector addition, use the {{c1::tip-to-tail}} method, or you can break the vector into its component parts and use the {{c1::Pythagorean Theorem}}

Tip-to-Tip Method:

Pythagorean Theorem Method:

Khan Academy Link
For vector subtraction, you must change the {{c1::direction}} of the subtracted vector and then do a tip-to-tail addition

Tip-to-Tip Method:

Khan Academy Link
Free body diagrams are representations of the {{c1::forces}} acting on an object
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Translational equilibrium::... equilibrium}} occurs in the absence of any net forces acting on an object
YouTube Link
{{c1::Rotational equilibrium::... equilibrium}} occurs in the absence of any net torques acting on an object
YouTube Link
Displacement is path {{c1::independent::dependent or independent}}
Khan Academy Link
Distance is path {{c1::dependent::dependent or independent}}
Khan Academy Link
Velocity is a {{c1::vector::vector or scalar}} and includes both {{c1::magnitude}} and {{c1::direction}}
Khan Academy Link
Speed is a {{c1::vector::vector or scalar}} and includes only the {{c1::magnitude of the rate of change}}
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::force}} is any push or pull that has the potential to result in an acceleration
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Gravity}} is the <u>attractive force</u> between two objects as a result of their <u>masses</u>
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Friction}} is a force that opposes motion as a function of electrostatic interactions at the surfaces between two objects

Static friction = stationary object 
Kinetic friction = sliding object



Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Mass}} is a measure of the inertia of an object; its amount of material
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Weight}} is the force experienced by a given mass due to the gravitational attraction to the Earth
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Acceleration}} is the vector representation of the change in velocity over time
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Torque}} is a twisting force that causes rotation
Khan Academy Link

Newton's first law of motion

{{c1::An object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by a net force > 0}}
Khan Academy Link

Newton's second law of motion

{{c1::Any acceleration is the result a net force > 0}}
Khan Academy Link

Newton's third law of motion

{{c1::For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction}}
Khan Academy Link

Units for joule

{{c1::}}

Joules are units of energy

A joule is  the amount of work you do when you exert a force of 1 newton to move an object a distance of 1 meter (1 newton meter or Nm)


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Kinetic energy::... energy}} is the energy of motion, observable as the movement of an object
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Potential energy::... energy}} is a type of energy an object has because of its <u>position</u>

The energy stored within a system


Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Gravitational potential energy::... energy}} is the potential an object has to do work as a result of being located at a particular position in a gravitational field
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Elastic potential energy::... energy}} is created when stretching or compressing an elastic object
