Describe the steps that make up the scientific method:

Initial steps: {{c1::formulate a hypothesis}}

Intermediate steps: {{c1::test that hypothesis}}

Final steps: {{c1::provide results for further testing of the hypothesis}}
Khan Academy Link
The FINER mnemonic is a framework used for formulating research questions. It asks, is the research {{c1::feasible}}, {{c1::interesting}}, {{c1::novel}}, {{c1::ethical}}, and {{c1::relevant}}?
YouTube Link

The four tenets of medical ethics are:

{{c1::Beneficence}}
{{c1::Nonmaleficence}}
{{c1::Respect for patient autonomy}}
{{c1::Justice}}
YouTube Link

The ethics of clinical research requires {{c1::equipoise}}, which is a state of genuine uncertainty on the part of the clinical investigator regarding which treatment is "better" for the study participant
Should the investigator discover that one treatment is of superior therapeutic merit, he or she is ethically obliged to offer that treatment
{{c1::Basic science research::... research}} occurs in a lab and does not include human subjects
Basic science research is often the best type for demonstrating causality because the experimenter has the highest degree of control over the experimental conditions
{{c1::Translational research::... research}} connects basic science research to clinical research
The {{c1::independent variable::... variable}} is the variable that is changed or controlled in a scientific experiment
YouTube Link
The {{c1::dependent variable::... variable}} is the variable a researcher is studying
YouTube Link
A {{c1::positive control::... control}} is a group in an experiment that receives a treatment with a known result, and therefore should show a particular change during the experiment

It is used to control for unknown variables during the experiment and to give the scientist something to compare with the test group


YouTube Link
A {{c1::negative control::... control}} group is a group in which no response is expected

It is the opposite of the positive control, in which a known response is expected


YouTube Link
{{c1::Validity}}, also known as {{c1::accuracy}}, is the degree to which the measurements of an experiment are true and accurate

This is not the same as reliability, which is the extent to which a measurement gives results that are very consistent


YouTube Link

When a scientist repeats an experiment with a different group of people or a different batch of the same chemicals and gets very <u>similar results</u> then those results are said to be {{c1::reliable}} or {{c1::precise}}
YouTube Link
A/an {{c1::research population}} is a well-defined collection of individuals or objects known to have similar characteristics
YouTube Link
A/an {{c1::research sample}} is a group of people, objects, or items that are taken from a larger population for measurement

The sample should be representative of the population to ensure that we can generalize the findings from the research sample to the population as a whole


YouTube Link
{{c1::Internal validity::... validity}} refers to how well an experiment is done, especially whether it avoids confounding variables that affect the measurements
YouTube Link
{{c1::External validity::... validity}} refers to the ability of a study to be generalized to the population that it describes
YouTube Link
A/an {{c1::within-subject design::... design}} is a type of experimental design in which all participants are exposed to every treatment or condition

The experiment controls for individual variations in a measurement by comparing the scores of a subject in one condition to the scores of the same subject in other conditions

So, the subject serves as its own control


YouTube Link
A/an {{c1::between-group design::... design}} is an experiment that has two or more groups of subjects each being tested by a different testing factor simultaneously
YouTube Link
In an experiment, a result has {{c1::statistical significance}} if it is unlikely to have occurred by chance
YouTube Link
{{c1::Clinical significance}} refers to the usefulness or importance of experimental findings to patient care or patient outcomes
YouTube Link
A/an {{c1::cohort study::... study}} is a particular form of longitudinal study that samples a cohort, performing a cross-section at intervals through time
YouTube Link
A/an {{c1::cross-sectional study::... study}} is defined as an observational research type that analyzes data of variables collected at one given point of time across a sample population
YouTube Link

A/an {{c1::case–control study::... study}} is a type of observational study in which two existing groups that differ in outcome are identified and compared on the basis of some supposed causal attribute
YouTube Link

The Hill criteria include the following 9 principles used to provide evidence of a causal relationship between a presumed cause and an observed effect:

{{c1::Temporality}}
{{c1::Plausibility}}
{{c1::Consistency}}
{{c1::Strength of association}}
{{c1::Dose response}}
{{c1::Reversibility}}
{{c1::Study design}}
{{c1::Evidence}}
YouTube Link
{{c1::Selection bias::... bias}} is the bias introduced by the selection of individuals, groups or data for analysis in such a way that proper randomization is not achieved

The sample obtained is not representative of the population


YouTube Link
{{c1::Detection bias::... bias}} arises from educated professionals using their knowledge in an inconsistent way by searching for an outcome disproportionately in certain populations
YouTube Link
The {{c1::Hawthorne effect}} is when the behavior of subjects is altered simply by knowing that they are being studied
YouTube Link
The {{c1::social desirability bias::... bias}} is a type of response bias that is the tendency of survey respondents to answer questions in a manner that will be viewed favorably by others
YouTube Link

The {{c1::placebo effect}} is a remarkable phenomenon in which a placebo -- a fake treatment, an inactive substance like sugar, distilled water, or saline solution -- can sometimes improve a patient's condition simply because the person has the expectation that it will be helpful.
YouTube Link
A {{c1::confounding variable::... variable}} is one that influences both the dependent variable and independent variable, causing a spurious association
YouTube Link
A {{c1::mediating variable::... variable}} is one that explains the relationship between the two other variables
YouTube Link
A {{c1::moderating variable::... variable}} is one that influences the strength of a relationship between two other variables
YouTube Link
The average of a set of numbers is called the {{c1::mean}}
Khan Academy Link
In a data set, the {{c1::median}} is the middle number; found by ordering all data points and picking out the one in the middle

Or, if there are two middle numbers, take the mean of those two numbers


Khan Academy Link
The number which appears most often in a set of numbers is called the {{c1::mode}}
Khan Academy Link
A normal distribution has a bell shape, the mean and median are {{c1::equal::equal or unequal}}, and {{c1::68%::%}} of the data falls within 1 standard deviation
Khan Academy Link
A normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1 is called a/an {{c1::standard normal distribution}}
Khan Academy Link
{{c1::Skewed distributions::... distributions}} have differences in their mean, median, and mode
Khan Academy Link
The distribution of this data is {{c1::left::left or right}} skewed; also known as {{c1::negatively::negatively or positively}} skewed
Khan Academy Link
The distribution of this data is {{c1::right::left or right}} skewed; also known as {{c1::positively::negatively or positively}} skewed
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::bimodal distribution::... distribution}} is a distribution with two different modes. These appear as distinct peaks (local maxima)
YouTube Link
The {{c1::range}} of a set of numbers is the highest number minus the lowest number
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::interquartile range}}, also called the midspread or middle 50% is equal to the difference between 75th and 25th percentiles, or between upper and lower quartiles
Khan Academy Link
The {{c1::standard deviation}} is a measure that is used to quantify the amount of variation or dispersion of a set of data values
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::outlier}} is a data point that differs significantly from other observations
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::histogram}} is a chart representing a frequency distribution; heights of the bars represent observed frequencies
Khan Academy Link
A/an {{c1::histogram}} presents numerical data whereas {{c1::bar graph}} shows categorical data
